Leader - establishing the atmosphere and motivating the subordinates.

Liaiser - developing and maintaining webs of contacts outside the organisation.

 

2. Informational

Monitor - collecting all types of information that are relevant and useful to the organisation.

Disseminator - transmitting information from outside the organisation to those inside.

Spokesman - transmitting information from inside the organisation to outsiders.

 

3. Decision-Making

Entrepreneur - initiating change and adapting to the environment.

Disturbance Handler - dealing with unexpected events.

Resource Allocator - deciding on the use of organisational resources.

Negotiator - negotiating with individuals and dealing with other organisations.

Question 14
Flexible plans that set out general guidelines are: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2022)
  • A.Strategic plans
  • B.Single use plans
  • C.Directional plans
  • D.Long term plans
Correct Answer: Directional plans

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Directional plans are flexible plans that set out general guidelines and provide a broad sense of direction for the organization. Unlike specific and detailed plans, directional plans offer more flexibility and adaptability to changing circumstances.

 

Let's understand the meanings of the other options to see why (C) Directional plans is the correct answer:

 

(A) Strategic plans: Strategic plans are long-term plans that outline the organization's overall objectives and the strategies to achieve those objectives. While they are essential for setting the organization's direction, they are generally more specific and detailed than directional plans.

 

(B) Single use plans: Single use plans are plans developed for a one-time project, event, or situation with a limited time frame. They are not necessarily flexible but are designed to address specific and unique situations.

 

(D) Long term plans: Long-term plans refer to plans that cover an extended period, typically several years. While they may provide a sense of direction, they are generally more specific and detailed in outlining the organization's goals and actions over the long term.

Question 15
Match List-A: Management Functions with their possible explanation List-B: (UGC NET HRM Jul 2018)List Ia. Controlling/Monitoringb. Leading/Motivatingc. Organisingd. PlanningList IIi. Making optimum use of the resources required to enable successfully carrying out the plans.ii. Deciding what needs to happen in future and generating plans for action.iii. Checking progress against plans, which may need modification based on feedback.iv. Getting others to play an effective part in achieving plans.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
  • D.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The correct match between the management functions (List I) and their possible explanations (List II) is Option D - [a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii]

 

a. Controlling/Monitoring - iii. Checking progress against plans, which may need modification based on feedback.

The function of controlling involves monitoring and measuring progress against established plans or standards. It includes comparing actual performance with desired outcomes, identifying deviations, and taking corrective action if necessary.

 

b. Leading/Motivating - iv. Getting others to play an effective part in achieving plans.

The function of leading and motivating involves influencing and guiding individuals or teams to contribute their efforts towards the accomplishment of organizational goals. This includes providing direction, support, and inspiration to facilitate goal attainment.

 

c. Organizing - i. Making optimum use of the resources required to enable successfully carrying out the plans.

The function of organizing involves structuring and arranging resources, including human resources, materials, and information, to facilitate the effective implementation of plans. It entails optimizing the allocation and utilization of resources to achieve desired outcomes.

 

d. Planning - ii. Deciding what needs to happen in the future and generating plans for action.

The function of planning involves determining future objectives and goals, analyzing the current situation, and developing strategies and action plans to achieve desired outcomes. It entails decision-making and setting the direction for the organization.

Question 16
Experienced managers have a simple and effective way to check whether their goals are good or not. They use the acronym “SMART”, which stands for: (UGC NET HRM Jul 2018)
  • A.Specific, Manageable, Attainable, Reasonable, and Timely
  • B.Sophisticated, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Targeted
  • C.Simple, Measurable, Ambitious, Relative, and Target oriented
  • D.Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Timely
Correct Answer: Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Timely

Correct answer is Option D.

 

The SMART acronym is a popular tool used in goal setting to ensure that goals are well-defined and have a higher chance of being successfully achieved. Here's what each letter of SMART represents:

 

Specific: Goals should be clear, specific, and well-defined. They should answer the questions of who, what, where, when, and why. Being specific helps to avoid ambiguity and provides a clear direction.

 

Measurable: Goals should be measurable so that progress and success can be quantified and tracked. Measurable goals have specific criteria or metrics that can be used to evaluate progress and determine when the goal has been achieved.

 

Attainable: Goals should be attainable or achievable. They should stretch individuals or teams to reach their full potential but still be within reach. Setting overly ambitious or unrealistic goals can lead to frustration and demotivation.

 

Relevant: Goals should be relevant or aligned with the overall objectives and strategies of the individual, team, or organization. They should contribute to the larger picture and have a meaningful impact on desired outcomes.

 

Timely: Goals should be time-bound or have a defined timeframe for completion. This helps create a sense of urgency, provides a deadline, and enables effective planning and prioritization.

 

By using the SMART criteria, managers can evaluate the quality and effectiveness of their goals.

Question 17
Consider the following. (UGC NET HRM Jul 2018)Assertion ‘A’:The basic planning process always involves setting objectives, forecasting, and assessing basic planning “premises” or assumptions, determining alternatives causes of actions, evaluating which options are best, and then choosing and implementing plan.Reason ‘R’:There is usually a hierarchical aspect to managerial planning. Top management approves a long-term or strategic plan. Then each department creates its own budgets and other plans to fit and to contribute to company’s long-term plan.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.Assertion ‘A’ is right and Reason ‘R’ is wrong.
  • B.Assertion ‘A’ is wrong and Reason ‘R’ is right.
  • C.Assertion ‘A’ and Reason ‘R’ both are right, Reason ‘R’ explains Assertion ‘A’.
  • D.Assertion ‘A’ and Reason ‘R’ both are right, Reason ‘R’ does not explain Assertion ‘A’.
Correct Answer: Assertion ‘A’ and Reason ‘R’ both are right, Reason ‘R’ explains Assertion ‘A’.

The assertion states that the basic planning process involves setting objectives, forecasting, assessing planning assumptions, determining alternative courses of action, evaluating options, and implementing the chosen plan. This is an accurate description of the general steps involved in the planning process.

 

The reason states that there is a hierarchical aspect to managerial planning, where top management approves a long-term or strategic plan, and each department creates its own plans and budgets to align with and contribute to the company's long-term plan. This hierarchical approach to planning is commonly observed in organizations.

 

The reason provides an additional explanation that supports the assertion. It explains how the planning process cascades from top management to various departments, ensuring alignment and coordination towards the overall organizational goals. Therefore, the reason explains the assertion.

 

Hence, the correct answer is Option C.

Question 18
According to which one of the following approaches, management is the function of planning, organising, leading and controlling? (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)
  • A.Process approach
  • B.Systems approach
  • C.Quantitative approach
  • D.Human behaviour approach
Correct Answer: Process approach

The correct answer is (A) Process approach.

 

The process approach views management as a set of interrelated functions that work together to achieve organizational goals. These functions are typically identified as planning, organizing, leading, and controlling, and they form the fundamental components of the management process. Let's understand the meanings of the other options to see why (A) Process approach is the correct answer:

 

(B) Systems approach: The systems approach to management considers an organization as an interconnected and interdependent system. It emphasizes understanding the relationships and interactions between various components of the organization to achieve its objectives. While the systems approach is relevant in management theory, it doesn't specifically identify management as a function of planning, organizing, leading, and controlling.

 

(C) Quantitative approach: The quantitative approach to management involves using mathematical and statistical techniques to analyze and solve management problems. It is focused on data-driven decision-making and optimization. While quantitative techniques are valuable tools in management, they do not encompass the broader functions of management as described in the question.

 

(D) Human behavior approach: The human behavior approach emphasizes the importance of understanding and managing human behavior in organizations. It focuses on motivation, leadership, communication, and group dynamics. While human behavior is a critical aspect of management, it does not capture the comprehensive set of management functions outlined in the question.

Question 19
Which of the following statements are correct? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2015)(a) Coordination means synchronisation of efforts with respect to time and direction.(b) The basic principles of coordination are direct contact and continuity of efforts.(c) In a given situation, cooperation may exist without coordination.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.only (a)
  • B.(b) only
  • C.(a) and (b)
  • D.(a), (b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c)

Option D is the correct answer.

 

(a) Coordination means synchronisation of efforts with respect to time and direction:

This statement is correct. Coordination is the process of linking the specialised activities of individuals and groups to one another and ensuring that a common purpose is served. According to James D Mooney and A C Reiley, “Co-ordination is the orderly arrangement of group efforts to provide unity of action in the pursuit of common purpose”.

 

(b) The basic principles of coordination are direct contact and continuity of efforts:

This statement is also correct. Direct contact refers to face-to-face communication and interaction between individuals or teams involved in a task or project, facilitating effective coordination. Continuity of efforts emphasizes the need for ongoing and consistent coordination to maintain progress and achieve desired outcomes.

 

(c) In a given situation, cooperation may exist without coordination:

This statement is correct as well. Cooperation refers to individuals or groups working together and assisting each other to achieve common goals. While cooperation can exist without formal coordination, it may not be as effective or efficient. Coordination helps ensure that cooperative efforts are aligned and integrated to achieve optimal results.

Question 20
Dinesh, a young executive, joinedSoftechco. three months back. Coming with a brilliant academic record, he played key role to revamp the company’s finance and management procedures for which he was recognized by the management. But now his performance has come down with mistakes found in most of his actions. Several things transpired against him. His only son turned spastic, and he was overlooked for promotion against a newcomer. This witnessed him becoming less popular among staff. Adding to that, a mild flirtation with a female employee was blown out of proportion. Dinesh hasbecameemotionally and professionally depressed with morale down and seemed losing self-confidence badly.(UGC NET Management Dec 2019)The HR manager should impart which of the following skills to Dinesh?
  • A.Technical skills
  • B.People skills
  • C.Communication skills
  • D.Negotiating skills
Correct Answer: People skills

Based on the given scenario, Dinesh is experiencing emotional and professional depression, a decline in performance, a decrease in popularity among staff, and a loss of self-confidence. These challenges indicate that Dinesh is facing difficulties in his interactions and relationships with others. Therefore, the HR manager should focus on imparting people skills to Dinesh to help him overcome these challenges and improve his overall performance and well-being.

 

People skills, also known as interpersonal or soft skills, refer to the ability to effectively interact, communicate, and build relationships with others. These skills are essential for successful collaboration, teamwork, and maintaining positive interpersonal dynamics in the workplace. By developing people skills, Dinesh can enhance his communication, teamwork, conflict resolution, and leadership abilities.

Question 21
Which of the following are creative problem-solving characteristics of effective managers? (UGC NET Management June 2021)1. Cognitive style2. Conceptual blocks3. Divergent thinking4. Activity balanceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1 and 3 only
  • B.2 and 3 only
  • C.1, 3 and 4 only
  • D.2, 3 and 4 only
Correct Answer: 2 and 3 only

The correct answer is (B) 2 and 3 only.

 

Let's go through each characteristic to see which ones are creative problem-solving characteristics of effective managers:

  • Cognitive style: Cognitive style refers to an individual's preferred way of processing and organizing information.
  • Conceptual blocks: Conceptual blocks are mental obstacles that hinder creative thinking and problem-solving. These blocks can include fixed mindsets, resistance to new ideas, and rigid thinking patterns. Overcoming conceptual blocks is crucial for fostering creative problem-solving.
  • Divergent thinking: Divergent thinking is a key characteristic of creative problem-solving. It involves generating a wide range of possible solutions or ideas in response to a problem. Effective managers often engage in divergent thinking to explore multiple options and find innovative solutions.
Question 22
Consider the following. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2013)(i) Planning is today’s action for tomorrow’s decision.(ii) Planning is forward looking while controlling is looking back.(iii) Motivation is about getting voluntary willingness of subordinates for action.(iv) Line and staff organization is the oldest form of organization.Select the correct statements from the codes given below:
  • A.(ii) and (iii) are correct.
  • B.(i), (ii) and (iv) are correct.
  • C.(i), (iii) and (iv) are correct
  • D.All are correct.
Correct Answer: (ii) and (iii) are correct.

Statement (ii) and (iii) are correct, while Statement (i) and (iv) are incorrect.

 

Statement (i): Planning is today’s action for tomorrow’s decision.

The above Statement is incorrect. Planning is the most basic of all managerial functions. It is the process by which managers establish goals and define the methods by which these goals are to be attained. Planning does not deal with future decisions. It deals with the futurity of present decisions. Decisions exist only in the present. The question that faces the strategic decision-maker is not what his should do tomorrow. It is, ‘What do we have to do today to be ready for an uncertain tomorrow?’ There are plans that lead to action today- and they are true plans, true strategic decisions. And there are plans that talk about action tomorrow- they are dreams.

 

Statement (ii): Planning is forward looking while controlling is looking back.

Planning and controlling are inseparable. Planning is the primary function of every organization, it is the thinking process, which mean looking ahead or making plans that how desired goal is achieved in future thus it is called a forward-looking function, on the other hand controlling is a systematic function which measures the actual performance with the planned performance. It compares and analyses the whole process of an organization and takes correcting actions. Thus, it is a backward-looking function.

 

Statement (iii): Motivation is about getting voluntary willingness of subordinates for action.

The above statement is correct. Motivation is the reason for people’s actions, willingness and goals. Motivation is derived from the word motive in the English language which is defined as a need that requires satisfaction. Motivation is one's direction to behaviour, or what causes a person to want to repeat a behaviour, a set of force that acts behind the motives. An individual's motivation may be inspired by others or events (extrinsic motivation) or it may come from within the individual (intrinsic motivation). Motivation has been considered as one of the most important reasons that inspires a person to move forward. Employees who are intrinsically motivated are more likely to engage in the task willingly as well as work to improve their skills, which will increase their capabilities.

 

Statement (iv): Line and staff organization is the oldest form of organization.

The above statement is incorrect as Line Organization is the oldest form of organization and not the Line and Staff Organization. The line of authority flows vertically from top-most executive to the lowest subordinate throughout the organization. Where, managers have direct authority over their respective subordinates through the chain of command. Whereas, In Line and Staff Organization, two types of authority relationship exist. They are staff and line authority. Staff authorities’ means authority to advice, support and serve the line managers. All managerial functions are practiced by line authority with the help of specialized skill of staff authority. It is modification of line organization and is more complex than it.

Question 23
Formulation of policies, programmes and procedures is the primary concern of: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2014)
  • A.Top Management
  • B.Middle Management
  • C.Operating Management
  • D.Both Operating and Middle Management
Correct Answer: Top Management

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Top management, which consists of executives and senior leaders within an organization, is responsible for strategic decision-making and setting the overall direction of the organization. Formulating policies, programs, and procedures is a critical function of top management as it involves establishing the guidelines, rules, and frameworks that guide the organization's activities and operations.

 

Top management's role in policy formulation includes determining the organization's mission, vision, and strategic objectives, as well as developing policies and programs that align with these goals. They create the broad guidelines and principles that govern the organization's operations, decision-making processes, and day-to-day activities.

 

Middle management and operating management also play a role in implementing and executing these policies, programs, and procedures established by top management. However, the primary responsibility for formulating these policies lies with top management.

Question 24
MBO was popularised as an approach to planning by: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2011)
  • A.P.F. Drucker
  • B.Henry Fayol
  • C.F. W. Taylor
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: P.F. Drucker

Option A is the correct answer.

 

MBO stands for Management by Objectives, and it was popularized as an approach to planning by Peter Drucker. Peter Drucker, a renowned management consultant, educator, and author, introduced and popularized the concept of Management by Objectives in his book "The Practice of Management," published in 1954.

 

Management by Objectives is a goal-setting and performance management approach that involves setting specific and measurable objectives collaboratively between managers and their subordinates. The process includes defining clear objectives, establishing action plans to achieve those objectives, and regularly reviewing progress towards achieving the goals. MBO aims to align individual and team objectives with the overall organizational goals, promoting employee motivation, and improving organizational performance.

Question 25
Arrange the time spent in administration in the increasing order by the following personnel: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)a. Works Managerb. Presidentc. Foremand. Board of Directorse. General ManagerChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.c, a, e, b, d
  • B.d, b, e, a, c
  • C.d, e, b, a, c
  • D.e, c, a, d, b
Correct Answer: c, a, e, b, d

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The correct order is from lower to top management.

 

c. Foreman < a. Works Manager < e. General Manager < b. President < d. Board of Directors

Question 26
One of the newer approaches to management theory is the managerial roles approach, popularized byProf.HenryMintzbergof McGill University. Essentially, his approach is to observe what managers actually do and from such observations come to the conclusion as to what managerial activities (or rules) are. Although many approaches have studied the actual work of managers – from chief executives to line supervisors –Mintzberghas given this approach a higher visibility.After systematically studying the activities of five chief executives in a variety of organizations,Mintzbergcame to the conclusion that executives do not perform the classical managerial functions – planning, organizing, co-ordinating and controlling. Instead, they engage in a variety of other activities. From his research and the research of others who have studied what managers actually do, he came to certain conclusions.Mintzberg’sapproach has also been criticized. In the first place, the sample of five executives used in his research is for too small to support so sweeping a conclusion. In the second place, inanalyzingthe actual activities of managers – from chief executives to supervisors – any researcher must realize that all managers do some work that is not purely managerial; one would expect even presidents of large companies to spend some of their time in public and stock holder relations, in fund raising and perhaps in dealer relations, marketing and so on.In the third place, many of the activitiesMintzbergfound are, in fact, evidences of planning, organizing, staffing, leading and controlling. For example, what is resource allocation but planning? The entrepreneurial role is certainly an element of planning. And the interpersonal roles are mainly instances of leading. In addition, the informational roles can be fitted into a number of functional areas.The new approach to management theory is:
  • A.Managerial roles approach
  • B.Workers’ participation approach
  • C.Executive role approach
  • D.‘Internal Management’ theory
Correct Answer: Managerial roles approach

As per the passage Managerial roles approach is one of the newer approaches to management theory.

 

“One of the newer approaches to management theory is the managerial roles approach, popularized by Prof. Henry Mintzberg of McGill University.”

Question 27
One of the newer approaches to management theory is the managerial roles approach, popularized byProf.HenryMintzbergof McGill University. Essentially, his approach is to observe what managers actually do and from such observations come to the conclusion as to what managerial activities (or rules) are. Although many approaches have studied the actual work of managers – from chief executives to line supervisors –Mintzberghas given this approach a higher visibility.After systematically studying the activities of five chief executives in a variety of organizations,Mintzbergcame to the conclusion that executives do not perform the classical managerial functions – planning, organizing, co-ordinating and controlling. Instead, they engage in a variety of other activities. From his research and the research of others who have studied what managers actually do, he came to certain conclusions.Mintzberg’sapproach has also been criticized. In the first place, the sample of five executives used in his research is for too small to support so sweeping a conclusion. In the second place, inanalyzingthe actual activities of managers – from chief executives to supervisors – any researcher must realize that all managers do some work that is not purely managerial; one would expect even presidents of large companies to spend some of their time in public and stock holder relations, in fund raising and perhaps in dealer relations, marketing and so on.In the third place, many of the activitiesMintzbergfound are, in fact, evidences of planning, organizing, staffing, leading and controlling. For example, what is resource allocation but planning? The entrepreneurial role is certainly an element of planning. And the interpersonal roles are mainly instances of leading. In addition, the informational roles can be fitted into a number of functional areas.The classical managerial functions are:
  • A.Planning & controlling
  • B.Supervising through officers, and decision making
  • C.Conducting training activities
  • D.All the above
Correct Answer: Planning & controlling

Correct answer can be inferred from the following statement:

 

“After systematically studying the activities of five chief executives in a variety of organizations, Mintzberg came to the conclusion that executives do not perform the classical managerial functions – planning, organizing, co-ordinating and controlling. Instead, they engage in a variety of other activities. From his research and the research of others who have studied what managers actually do, he came to certain conclusions.”

Question 28
One of the newer approaches to management theory is the managerial roles approach, popularized byProf.HenryMintzbergof McGill University. Essentially, his approach is to observe what managers actually do and from such observations come to the conclusion as to what managerial activities (or rules) are. Although many approaches have studied the actual work of managers – from chief executives to line supervisors –Mintzberghas given this approach a higher visibility.After systematically studying the activities of five chief executives in a variety of organizations,Mintzbergcame to the conclusion that executives do not perform the classical managerial functions – planning, organizing, co-ordinating and controlling. Instead, they engage in a variety of other activities. From his research and the research of others who have studied what managers actually do, he came to certain conclusions.Mintzberg’sapproach has also been criticized. In the first place, the sample of five executives used in his research is for too small to support so sweeping a conclusion. In the second place, inanalyzingthe actual activities of managers – from chief executives to supervisors – any researcher must realize that all managers do some work that is not purely managerial; one would expect even presidents of large companies to spend some of their time in public and stock holder relations, in fund raising and perhaps in dealer relations, marketing and so on.In the third place, many of the activitiesMintzbergfound are, in fact, evidences of planning, organizing, staffing, leading and controlling. For example, what is resource allocation but planning? The entrepreneurial role is certainly an element of planning. And the interpersonal roles are mainly instances of leading. In addition, the informational roles can be fitted into a number of functional areas.Mintzberg’sapproach is:
  • A.A fool proof approach without any demerits & criticism.
  • B.Faced with some criticism.
  • C.Considered as innovative and without shortcomings.
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Faced with some criticism.

As per passage, Mintzberg approach faced with some crticicism.

Question 29
One of the newer approaches to management theory is the managerial roles approach, popularized byProf.HenryMintzbergof McGill University. Essentially, his approach is to observe what managers actually do and from such observations come to the conclusion as to what managerial activities (or rules) are. Although many approaches have studied the actual work of managers – from chief executives to line supervisors –Mintzberghas given this approach a higher visibility.After systematically studying the activities of five chief executives in a variety of organizations,Mintzbergcame to the conclusion that executives do not perform the classical managerial functions – planning, organizing, co-ordinating and controlling. Instead, they engage in a variety of other activities. From his research and the research of others who have studied what managers actually do, he came to certain conclusions.Mintzberg’sapproach has also been criticized. In the first place, the sample of five executives used in his research is for too small to support so sweeping a conclusion. In the second place, inanalyzingthe actual activities of managers – from chief executives to supervisors – any researcher must realize that all managers do some work that is not purely managerial; one would expect even presidents of large companies to spend some of their time in public and stock holder relations, in fund raising and perhaps in dealer relations, marketing and so on.In the third place, many of the activitiesMintzbergfound are, in fact, evidences of planning, organizing, staffing, leading and controlling. For example, what is resource allocation but planning? The entrepreneurial role is certainly an element of planning. And the interpersonal roles are mainly instances of leading. In addition, the informational roles can be fitted into a number of functional areas.The entrepreneurial role means:
  • A.Leading
  • B.Element of planning
  • C.Playing pivotal role in Industrial Relations
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: Element of planning

Option B is the correct answer. As per passage last line:

 

“The entrepreneurial role is certainly an element of planning. And the interpersonal roles are mainly instances of leading. In addition, the informational roles can be fitted into a number of functional areas.”

Question 30
One of the newer approaches to management theory is the managerial roles approach, popularized byProf.HenryMintzbergof McGill University. Essentially, his approach is to observe what managers actually do and from such observations come to the conclusion as to what managerial activities (or rules) are. Although many approaches have studied the actual work of managers – from chief executives to line supervisors –Mintzberghas given this approach a higher visibility.After systematically studying the activities of five chief executives in a variety of organizations,Mintzbergcame to the conclusion that executives do not perform the classical managerial functions – planning, organizing, co-ordinating and controlling. Instead, they engage in a variety of other activities. From his research and the research of others who have studied what managers actually do, he came to certain conclusions.Mintzberg’sapproach has also been criticized. In the first place, the sample of five executives used in his research is for too small to support so sweeping a conclusion. In the second place, inanalyzingthe actual activities of managers – from chief executives to supervisors – any researcher must realize that all managers do some work that is not purely managerial; one would expect even presidents of large companies to spend some of their time in public and stock holder relations, in fund raising and perhaps in dealer relations, marketing and so on.In the third place, many of the activitiesMintzbergfound are, in fact, evidences of planning, organizing, staffing, leading and controlling. For example, what is resource allocation but planning? The entrepreneurial role is certainly an element of planning. And the interpersonal roles are mainly instances of leading. In addition, the informational roles can be fitted into a number of functional areas.The Managerial Role approach relates to:
  • A.What workers’ actually do while participating in management?
  • B.What managers actually do?
  • C.What the various authorities in the area of Industrial Relations actually do?
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: What managers actually do?

Option B is the correct answer.

 

“One of the newer approaches to management theory is the managerial roles approach, popularized by Prof. Henry Mintzberg of McGill University. Essentially, his approach is to observe what managers actually do and from such observations come to the conclusion as to what managerial activities (or rules) are.”

Question 31
Which of the following is a general statement that guides or channels thinking in decision-making? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2015)
  • A.Strategy
  • B.Policy
  • C.Rule
  • D.Procedure
Correct Answer: Policy

A policy is a general statement that guides or channels thinking in decision-making within an organization. It provides a broad framework and direction for making choices and taking actions in various situations.

 

Let's understand the meanings of the other options to see why (B) Policy is the correct answer:

 

(A) Strategy: A strategy is a plan or course of action designed to achieve specific objectives or goals. While strategies guide the overall direction and approach of the organization, they are more concerned with the broader approach to achieving success rather than providing specific guidelines for decision-making.

 

(C) Rule: A rule is a specific and detailed statement that prescribes what should or should not be done in a particular situation. Rules are more rigid and less flexible than policies, as they leave little room for interpretation or adaptation.

 

(D) Procedure: A procedure is a step-by-step set of instructions that outlines how a specific task or activity should be carried out. Procedures are more detailed than policies and are used to ensure consistency and efficiency in performing tasks.

Question 32
Which of the following are "Feedforward" control measures for reducing workplace violence? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)a. Investigate incidences and take appropriate action.b. Train employees about how to avoid danger if situation arises.c. Review company policies and change these policies, if necessary.d. Clearly communicate policies to employees.e. Observe how employees treat and interact with each other.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a and c only
  • B.c and e only
  • C.b and d only
  • D.b, d and e only
Correct Answer: b and d only

The "Feedforward" control measures for reducing workplace violence include training employees about how to avoid danger if a situation arises and clearly communicating policies to employees. Therefore, option C, which includes only these two measures, is the most appropriate answer.

 

Option a includes investigating incidents and taking appropriate action, which is a reactive control measure rather than a feedforward one.

 

Option c includes reviewing company policies and changing them, which is a corrective control measure.

 

Option e includes observing how employees treat and interact with each other, which is a concurrent control measure rather than a feedforward one.

Question 33
Which one of the following is NOT a characteristic of a manager? [UGC NET Management June 2022]
  • A.Does the right thing
  • B.Imitates
  • C.Asks how and when
  • D.Accepts the status quo
Correct Answer: Does the right thing

The question is related to characteristics of a manager vs. characteristics of a leader.

 

The distinctive features of a Manager Vs. Leader are as follows:

Manager

Leader

Does things right

Does the right thing

Imitates

Originates

Asks how and when

Asks what and why

Accepts the status quo

Challenges the status quo

 

Thus, option A is correct.

Question 34
According to Henry Fayol, which one of the following combinations of qualities are required in a manager? (UGC NET Management Aug 2016)
  • A.Physical, mental, experience, educational and conceptual
  • B.Technical, human, conceptual, mental and moral
  • C.Physical, mental, moral, educational, technical and experience
  • D.Mental, moral, conceptual, educational, technical and experience
Correct Answer: Physical, mental, moral, educational, technical and experience

According to Henry Fayol, the combination of qualities required in a manager is:

 

(C) Physical, mental, moral, educational, technical, and experience.

 

Henry Fayol, a prominent management theorist, identified these six qualities as essential for effective management:

 

1. Physical: A manager should possess the physical stamina and energy required to handle the demands of the job, as managerial roles can be physically demanding.

2. Mental: This refers to having good cognitive abilities, intelligence, and problem-solving skills to make sound decisions and solve complex issues.

3. Moral: Managers should have strong ethical values and integrity, as they are responsible for setting a moral example for their subordinates and the organization.

4. Educational: A well-rounded education provides managers with the necessary knowledge and understanding of various subjects related to their field and industry.

5. Technical: Managers need to have a certain level of technical expertise related to the industry they are working in to understand the operational aspects and guide their team effectively.

6. Experience: Practical experience is valuable for managers as it helps them apply their knowledge effectively and deal with real-world situations.

Question 35
Identify the correct sequence of control cycle: (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Feedback → Evaluation → Adjustment → Action
  • B.Action → Evaluation → Feedback → Adjustment
  • C.Action → Feedback → Evaluation → Adjustment
  • D.Adjustment → Action → Feedback → Evaluation
Correct Answer: Action → Feedback → Evaluation → Adjustment

The correct sequence of the control cycle is:

 

(C) Action → Feedback → Evaluation → Adjustment.

 

In the control cycle, the steps are typically as follows:

 

1. Action: This is the initial step where the planned activities or processes are executed.

2. Feedback: After the action is taken, feedback is collected through various means, such as reports, data, or observations.

3. Evaluation: The collected feedback is then analyzed and evaluated to assess whether the actual performance aligns with the desired goals or standards.

4. Adjustment: Based on the evaluation, necessary adjustments or corrections are made to improve performance and achieve the desired outcomes.

Quiz Attempt #118938

Total Questions: 12
Question 1
Match List I with List II: (UGC NET Management Jun 2023)LIST I (Emphases of OB)a. Macro-appliedb. Micro-appliedc. Macro-theoreticald. Micro-theoreticalLIST II (Related Disciplines)i. Organisation Developmentii. Organisational Behaviouriii. Human Resource Managementiv. Organisation TheoryChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a - ii, b -iii, c -iv, d -i
  • B.a -i, b - iii, c- iv, d - ii
  • C.a -i, b - iv, c- iii, d - ii
  • D.a - iii, b - ii, c -i, d - iv
Correct Answer: a -i, b - iii, c- iv, d - ii

The correct answer is (B).

 

a. Macro-applied → Organisation Development (i)

Macro-applied emphasis deals with large-scale, practical applications in organizations, focusing on improving overall organizational effectiveness and change — which relates to Organisation Development (OD).

 

b. Micro-applied → Human Resource Management (iii)

Micro-applied focus is on practical, individual-level application within organizations, which aligns with Human Resource Management (HRM), addressing issues like recruitment, training, and employee relations.

 

c. Macro-theoretical → Organisation Theory (iv)

Macro-theoretical emphasis refers to the theoretical frameworks and structures at the organizational level, which is studied under Organisation Theory.

 

d. Micro-theoretical → Organisational Behaviour (ii)

Micro-theoretical focuses on theories related to individual and group behavior within organizations, the core focus of Organisational Behaviour (OB).

Question 2
The S-O-B-C model of organisational behaviour identifies 4 major variables, which are related to another. Which of the following stands for the letter ‘S’? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2023)
  • A.Structure
  • B.Stimulus
  • C.System
  • D.Social
Correct Answer: Stimulus

Fred E Luthans has explained the conceptual framework of OB in form of the S-O-B-C Model. It is based on the philosophy that ‘human behaviour is caused and follows the cause-effect relationship’. SOBC stands for Stimulus, Organism, Behaviour, Consequences. The order is Stimulus > Organism > Behaviour > Consequences.

 

Stimuli (S) or Situation: They include overt and covert stimuli, or physical, socio-cultural, international, and technological environment. These stimuli constitute physical settings and external situations that affect reactions or responses of people; they make people react or respond. Organisational culture is the most important determinant of situational behaviour. Organisational structures, management processes, and job design are major situational inputs (stimuli) that affect people’s behaviour. Organisational structure consists of designations, roles, and positions. Management processes include decision-making, control, communication, power, and goal setting. Job design shows systematic arrangement of job contents, including job title, location, duties, working conditions, responsibility, skills, knowledge, rewards, relations, timing, and so forth.

Question 3
Match List I with List II. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)List I (Motive of humanbehaviorin organizations)A) AchievementB) ControlC) ExtensionD) DependencyList II (Characteristic)I) Concern for othersII) Concern for self-developmentIII) Concern for excellenceIV) Concern for orderlinessChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-IV, B-III. C-II, D-I
  • C.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II

The correct answer is (D) A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II.

 

A) Achievement — Concern for excellence (III)

The achievement motive reflects an individual’s desire to excel, set high standards, and continuously strive for excellence in performance.

 

B) Control — Concern for orderliness (IV)

The control motive relates to maintaining discipline, structure, and order. People with this motive prefer clear rules, systems, and organized work environments.

 

C) Extension — Concern for others (I)

The extension motive is about caring for others, helping colleagues, and contributing to the welfare of the larger group or society.

 

D) Dependency — Concern for self-development (II)

The dependency motive refers to seeking guidance, learning from others, and focusing on personal growth and self-development through support and mentoring.

Question 4
The aspect of management that is concerned with the individuals, their roles, the dyads, the teams and the entire organization is: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2014)
  • A.Human Resource Management
  • B.Human Resource Development
  • C.Organizational Behaviour
  • D.Organizational Culture
Correct Answer: Organizational Behaviour

The aspect of management that is concerned with the individuals, their roles, the dyads, the teams and the entire organization is Organization Behaviour.

 

Robbins (1198) defined Organizational Behaviour as a field of study that investigates the impact that individuals, groups and structures have on behaviour within organizations for the purpose of applying such knowledge towards improving an organization’s effectiveness.

 

The recent progressive trends have redefined organization behaviour as the study and application of how people – as individuals and as groups – act within organizations. It is an interdisciplinary behavioural science studying phenomenon and dynamics (processes) of organizations, their various human units (individuals, roles, dyads, teams, inter-teams, organizations) and the organization-environment interface.

 

The other options of the question described below:

 

Human Resource Management is the process of recruiting, selecting, inducting employees, providing orientation, imparting training and development, appraising the performance of employees, deciding compensation and providing benefits, motivating employees, maintaining proper relations with employees and their trade unions, ensuring employees safety, welfare and health measures in compliance with labour laws of the land.

 

Human Resource Development (HRD) is the framework for helping employees develop their personal and organizational skills, knowledge, and abilities. It includes such opportunities as employee training, employee career development, performance management and development, coaching, mentoring, succession planning, key employee identification and organization development.

 

The organisational culture is a system of shared beliefs and attitudes that develop within an organisation and guides the behaviour of its members. The corporate culture consists of the normal values and unwritten rules of conduct of an organisation as well as management styles, priorities, beliefs and inters personal behaviour that prevails. Together they create a climate that influences how will people communicate, plan and make decisions.

Question 5
SOBC model is used to identify the major variables in organizational behaviour and to show how they relate to another. Choose from the following, the alternative that gives the correct terms for the letters SOBC. (UGC NET HRM Jun 2020)
  • A.Structure, Organisation, Behaviour, Cognition
  • B.Stimulus, Organisation, Behaviour, Control
  • C.Stimulus, Organism, Behaviour, Consequences
  • D.Structure, Opportunity, Behaviour, Consequences
Correct Answer: Stimulus, Organism, Behaviour, Consequences

The SOBC model provides us with a mechanism for systematically considering human behaviour in organizations. SOBC is a sequence in which:

S represents the Stimulus situation (such things as light, sounds, job demands, supervisors, co-workers’ characteristics and equipment); 

O (Organism) refers to the characteristics of the person, including personality, needs, attitudes, values and intentions; 

B refers to the person’s Behavioural responses or actions in the situation under consideration; and, finally, 

C represents the Consequences or outcomes associated with the behavioural responses. 

Question 6
Which of the following statements about the Organisational Behaviour (OB) system is/are true and false? (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)(a) OB believes in open system.(b) It has three sub-systems namely formal Organisation System, Individual System and Social System.(c) There are no intervening mechanisms to lead Organisational Behaviour towards organisational effectiveness.(d) OB Mod and reinforcement are outside the purview of OB system.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a), (b), (c) are true, (d) is false.
  • B.(a), (c), (d) are true, (b) is false.
  • C.(a), (c) are true, (b) and (d) are false.
  • D.(a) and (b) are true, (c) and (d) are false.
Correct Answer: (a) and (b) are true, (c) and (d) are false.

Let's break down the statements and their accuracy:

 

a) OB believes in open system.

True. Organizational Behavior (OB) often operates on the premise of an open system, acknowledging that organizations interact and are influenced by their external environment.

 

(b) It has three sub-systems, namely formal Organization System, Individual System, and Social System.

True. OB is often divided into these sub-systems to study and understand different aspects such as the formal structure, individual behavior, and the social dynamics within an organization.

 

(c) There are no intervening mechanisms to lead Organizational Behavior towards organizational effectiveness.

False. Intervening mechanisms, such as management practices, leadership styles, organizational culture, training programs, and incentive systems, are frequently employed within OB to guide and influence behavior towards achieving organizational effectiveness.

 

(d) OB Mod and reinforcement are outside the purview of the OB system.

False. Organizational Behavior Modification (OB Mod) and reinforcement strategies are often included within the scope of OB. They involve using behavioral theories and techniques to modify and reinforce desired behaviors within an organization.

 

Therefore, the correct answer based on the accuracy of the statements provided would be (D) - (a) and (b) are true, while (c) and (d) are false.

Question 7
Which of the following statements about Organizational Behaviour is wrong? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)
  • A.It is an inter-disciplinary subject.
  • B.It believes that individual, group, and organization are subsystems of OB.
  • C.Its explanation find roots in systems as well as contingency theories.
  • D.It deals only with prediction of human behaviour at work.
Correct Answer: It deals only with prediction of human behaviour at work.

The incorrect statement among the options provided is (D) - "It deals only with the prediction of human behavior at work."

 

Organizational Behavior (OB) is a multidisciplinary field that encompasses various aspects beyond solely predicting human behavior at work. While understanding and predicting human behavior in the workplace is a significant component of OB, it also involves studying and addressing various other factors such as organizational culture, structure, leadership, motivation, group dynamics, decision-making, and conflict resolution. OB aims to comprehend how individuals, groups, and organizations function and interact within work settings, enabling better management and improvement of organizational effectiveness and employee well-being.

Question 8
Match the items of List-II with the items of List-I and indicate the code of correct matching. (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)List-I (Model of Organizational Behaviour)(a) Autocratic(b) Custodial(c) Supportive(d) CollegialList-II (Employee Orientation)(i) Responsible behaviour(ii) Security and benefits(iii) Job performance(iv) Obedience
  • A.a- (iv), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(i)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(i), b-(iv), c-(iii), d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a- (iv), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(i)

The question deals with various models of organizational behavior and their corresponding employee orientations.

 

1. Autocratic Model: This model reflects an organizational structure where decision-making power is concentrated at the top. Employees are expected to follow instructions without much involvement in decision-making processes. In this model, obedience to authority is a key expectation from employees, hence matching with the orientation of 'Obedience' in List II.

 

2. Custodial Model: This model emphasizes providing a sense of security and benefits to employees. Organizations following this model focus on employee welfare programs, benefits, job security, and stability. Thus, it aligns with the 'Security and benefits' orientation in List II.

 

3. Supportive Model: In this model, organizations emphasize nurturing and supporting employees' job performance. There's a focus on teamwork, support mechanisms, and development opportunities to enhance job performance, linking it with the 'Job performance' orientation in List II.

 

4. Collegial Model: This model represents a more democratic and participative approach to organizational behavior. It encourages responsible behavior among employees, promoting collaboration, mutual respect, and shared decision-making. This aligns with the 'Responsible behavior' orientation in List II.

 

Therefore, the correct matching of models of organizational behavior in List I with their respective employee orientations in List II is:

 

(a) Autocratic - (iv) Obedience

(b) Custodial - (ii) Security and benefits

(c) Supportive - (iii) Job performance

(d) Collegial - (i) Responsible behavior

Question 9
Match the below mentioned aspects with their main behavioural disciplines: (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)Aspects(a) Leadership and stress management(b) Group conflict management(c) Cross-cultural analysis(d) PowerBehavioural discipline(i) Psychology(ii) Anthropology(iii) Sociology and Psychology(iv) Political science
  • A.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • C.a-(i), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(iv)

Let's match the aspects with their respective behavioral disciplines:

 

(a) Leadership and stress management - (ii) Anthropology

Anthropology helps understand leadership and stress management by studying cultural influences, social structures, and practices that impact these aspects within different groups and societies.

 

(b) Group conflict management - (iii) Sociology and Psychology

Sociology and Psychology both play roles in understanding group dynamics and conflict resolution. Sociology delves into group behaviors and structures, while Psychology explores individual behaviors and their impact on group conflicts.

 

(c) Cross-cultural analysis - (i) Psychology

Psychology aids in cross-cultural analysis by examining individual behaviors, perceptions, and cognitive processes across different cultures and societies.

 

(d) Power - (iv) Political science

Political science extensively studies power dynamics, authority, and influence within political systems and institutions, making it well-suited to analyze the concept of power within organizations and society.

 

Therefore, the correct matching of aspects with their main behavioral disciplines is:

 

(a) Leadership and stress management - (ii) Anthropology

(b) Group conflict management - (iii) Sociology and Psychology

(c) Cross-cultural analysis - (i) Psychology

(d) Power - (iv) Political science

Question 10
Match the items of List I with those of List II. (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)List I Behavioral science(a) Anthropology(b) Psychology(c) Social psychology(d) SociologyList II Contribution(i) Attitude change(ii) Attitude measurement(iii) Conflict(iv) Organizational culture
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(i)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(iii), d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iii)

The correct answer is (B) a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii).

 

Anthropology - Organizational culture (iv)

Anthropology studies human societies and cultures. In the context of organizational behavior, it examines how cultures develop within organizations, how they are sustained, and how they impact behavior and interactions among employees. Understanding the cultural aspects within an organization helps in comprehending the shared values, beliefs, and norms that influence the working environment.

 

Psychology - Attitude measurement (ii)

Psychology, as a scientific study of the mind and behavior, contributes to understanding attitudes and their measurement. Attitudes play a significant role in shaping individual behavior in an organizational setting. Psychologists develop tools and methodologies to measure attitudes, which are essential for understanding employee opinions, job satisfaction, and behavioral patterns.

 

Social psychology - Attitude change (i)

Social psychology combines elements from psychology and sociology, focusing on how individuals' behavior and attitudes are influenced by social interactions. It contributes to understanding attitude change, persuasion, and the impact of social influence on individual behavior within groups or organizations.

 

Sociology - Conflict (iii)

Sociology studies human social behavior within the context of larger social structures. In organizations, sociologists explore conflicts arising from differences in power dynamics, role expectations, and structural aspects. They analyze how conflicts emerge, escalate, and can potentially be managed or resolved within organizational settings.

Question 11
Match the items of List II with the items of List I and indicate the code of correct matching.. (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)List I(a) Organization Man(b) Self-actualizing Man(c) Complex Man(d) Rational-Economic ManList II(i) Maximizing self-interest.(ii) Using capabilities to develop a sense of creating certain things.(iii) Sacrificing individuality for the sake of group.(iv) Understanding human needs may not be the final step in understanding human behavior.
  • A.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(ii)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(iv), d-(i)
  • C.a-(i), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(iii)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(iv), d-(i)

(a) Organization Man - Sacrificing individuality for the sake of group.

(b) Self-actualizing Man - Using capabilities to develop a sense of creating certain things.

(c) Complex Man - Understanding human needs may not be the final step in understanding human behaviour.

(d) Rational-Economic Man - Maximizing self-interest.

 

The correct answer is (B) a-(iii) b-(ii) c-(iv) d-(i).

 

Organization Man - Sacrificing individuality for the sake of the group (iii)

Organization Man refers to the concept that individuals, within an organizational context, tend to prioritize the interests of the group or organization over their individual interests. This concept emphasizes the significance of loyalty, cooperation, and adherence to organizational norms and values.

 

Self-actualizing Man - Using capabilities to develop a sense of creating certain things (ii)

Self-actualizing Man relates to the concept introduced by Maslow, where individuals aim to reach their fullest potential, focusing on personal growth, creativity, and the utilization of their skills and capabilities to achieve self-fulfillment.

 

Complex Man - Understanding human needs may not be the final step in understanding human behavior (iv)

Complex Man represents the understanding that human behavior is intricate and cannot be fully explained or predicted solely by identifying and fulfilling basic needs. It acknowledges the multifaceted nature of human behavior influenced by various factors, making predictions challenging.

 

Rational-Economic Man - Maximizing self-interest (i)

Rational-Economic Man suggests that individuals, in decision-making situations, act in a manner to maximize their self-interests. This model assumes that individuals make rational choices based on their economic considerations and aims to maximize their benefits.

 

These behavioral models or concepts help in understanding human behavior within organizational contexts, shedding light on different perspectives and motivations that guide individuals' actions and decisions in the workplace.

Question 12
The conceptual foundation of OB are anchored in the Behavioural Sciences of Psychology, Anthropology, and Political Science. Match the Behavioural Science Source (List – B) of the OB Topics (List – A). (UGC NET HRM Jul 2016)List – A (OB Topics)a. Interpersonal stylesb. Societal Culturec. Power & PoliticsList – B (Relevant Behavioural Science Source)i. Political Scienceii. Anthropologyiii. Psychology
  • A.a-iii, b-ii, c-i
  • B.a-i, b-ii, c-iii
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-ii
  • D.a-i, b-iii, c-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-ii, c-i

a. Interpersonal styles – Psychology

Psychology is the science of behaviour and mind. Psychology includes the study of conscious and unconscious phenomena, as well as feeling and thought. Psychologists explore behaviour and mental processes, including perception, cognition, attention, emotion (affect), intelligence, phenomenology, motivation (conation), brain functioning, and personality. This extends to interaction between people, such as interpersonal relationships, including psychological resilience, family resilience, and other areas.

 

b. Societal Culture – Anthropology

Anthropology is a global discipline involving humanities, social sciences and natural sciences. Anthropology builds upon knowledge from natural sciences, including the discoveries about the origin and evolution of Homo sapiens, human physical traits, human behaviour, the variations among different groups of humans, how the evolutionary past of Homo sapiens has influenced its social organization and culture, and from social sciences, including the organization of human social and cultural relations, institutions, social conflicts, etc. 

 

c. Power & Politics – Political Science

Political science is a social science which deals with systems of governance, and the analysis of political activities, political thoughts, and political behaviour. It deals extensively with the theory and practice of politics which is commonly thought of as determining of the distribution of power and resources.

Quiz Attempt #118939

Total Questions: 3
Question 1
Psychological factors of individual behaviour will include which of the following? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)a. Perceptionb. written skillsc. Valuesd. Economic statuse. AttitudesChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b, c only
  • B.a, c, e only
  • C.b, d, e only
  • D.b, c, e only
Correct Answer: a, c, e only

In considering psychological factors influencing individual behavior:

 

a. Perception: How individuals interpret and make sense of information from their environment. Perception significantly influences decision-making and behavior.

 

b. Written skills: Although an important skill, it's more related to cognitive abilities rather than direct psychological factors affecting behavior.

 

c. Values: These are the beliefs and principles that guide an individual's behavior and decision-making. Values play a crucial role in shaping attitudes and behaviors.

 

d. Economic status: While economic status can influence behavior, it's more related to socio-economic factors and might not be considered a direct psychological factor in individual behavior.

 

e. Attitudes: Represent an individual's evaluation or feelings about something, affecting behavior towards that object or situation.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate options from the given choices (a, c, e) cover perception, values, and attitudes, which are indeed psychological factors impacting individual behavior.

Question 2
Assertion (A):The interest in human relations at work has become very popular in modern days. (UGC NET Management Aug 2016)Reason (R):Social pressures brought increasing pressures for an improved human climate in organizations.
  • A.Assertion A and Reasoning R both are correct and R is correct explanation of A.
  • B.Assertion A and Reasoning R both are correct, but R is not right explanationofA.
  • C.Assertion A is correct, whereas Reasoning R is incorrect.
  • D.Reasoning R is correct, whereas Assertion A is incorrect.
Correct Answer: Assertion A and Reasoning R both are correct and R is correct explanation of A.

The assertion claims that there is a contemporary rise in interest concerning human relations at work, which is indeed accurate. The reason provided, stating that social pressures have led to a demand for an improved human climate within organizations, also seems valid and aligns with the assertion. This explanation supports the assertion by attributing the increased interest in human relations to external factors like social pressures.

 

Therefore, option (A) seems appropriate here as both the assertion and the reason are correct, and the reason provides a suitable explanation for the assertion, linking the rise in interest to the influence of social pressures.

Question 3
Match the items in List - I and List - II (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)List - I (Individual Behaviour Models)(a) Theory X and Y model(b) Economic model(c) Behavioural model(d) Rational modelList-II (Contributory)(i) Freud(ii) F.W. Taylor(iii) Douglas Mc Gregor(iv) ChrisArgyris
  • A.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
  • C.a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-ii
  • D.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i

Here's an explanation of the Individual Behaviour Models matched with their respective contributors:

 

Theory X and Y model (a) → Douglas McGregor (iii): Douglas McGregor introduced Theory X and Theory Y in the field of management. Theory X represents a traditional view of employees as inherently lazy and needing strict supervision, while Theory Y suggests that employees are inherently motivated, responsible, and capable of self-direction and self-control.

 

Economic model (b) → F.W. Taylor (ii): Frederick Winslow Taylor, known as the father of scientific management, contributed to the economic model of individual behavior in organizations. He focused on optimizing productivity and efficiency through scientific methods and emphasized financial incentives to motivate workers.

 

Behavioural model (c) → Chris Argyris (iv): Chris Argyris contributed to the behavioral model by exploring theories related to human behavior in organizations. He focused on understanding how individuals interact within the organizational environment, emphasizing learning, motivation, and how organizational structures affect behavior.

 

Rational model (d) → Freud (i): Sigmund Freud, a prominent figure in psychology, laid the groundwork for the rational model. Although primarily known for psychoanalysis, his theories about the human mind and behavior, particularly the unconscious mind, have influenced various perspectives on individual behavior in organizational settings.

 

These contributions have significantly shaped the understanding of individual behavior within organizations, offering different lenses through which managers perceive and manage employee behavior and motivation.

Quiz Attempt #118940

Total Questions: 13
Question 1
Match the List-I with List-II. (UGC NET HRM Jun 2024)List I (Propoundersof management thought)A. Charles BabbageB. Robert OwenC. Max WeberD. Fred LuthansList II (Explanation)I. Development of personnelII. Runningorganisationinmorerational manner instead of traditional authority or charismatic authorityIII. A systemview pointmay provide the impetus to unify management theoryIV. WorkspecialisationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
  • C.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • D.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III

The correct answer is option (B) A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III.

 

A. Charles Babbage → IV. Work specialisation

Babbage emphasized division of labor and work specialization to increase productivity, which is linked to modern management concepts.

 

B. Robert Owen → I. Development of personnel

Owen is known for his early work on improving working conditions and emphasizing the welfare and development of workers.

 

C. Max Weber → II. Running organisation in more rational manner instead of traditional authority or charismatic authority

Weber is famous for his theory of bureaucracy, advocating rational-legal authority over traditional or charismatic authority.

 

D. Fred Luthans → III. A system viewpoint may provide the impetus to unify management theory

Luthans is known for his contributions to the development of systems theory in management, viewing organizations as complex systems with interacting components.

Question 2
Robert Owen, the founder of ‘Welfare Movement’ conducted which of the following experiments? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2010)
  • A.New Lanark Experiment
  • B.Hawthorne Experiment
  • C.Experiment on Illumination
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: New Lanark Experiment

Robert Owen, known as the "Father of Personnel Management," conducted an extraordinary experiment in the group of textile mills at New Lanark in Scotland between 1800 and 1828. During this experiment, Owen implemented various reforms to improve the working conditions within the factory. He raised the minimum working age for children, reduced the hours of work for employees, and aimed to enhance the overall well-being of the community in which his employees resided. As part of his efforts, Owen constructed houses and streets, transforming both the factory and the community into an attractive and livable environment. Therefore, the correct answer is A – New Lanark Experiment.

Question 3
The ‘New Lanark’ experiment is associated with: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2013)
  • A.Human Relations at workplace
  • B.Networking Organisations
  • C.Welfare Movement in Industries
  • D.Behavioural Theory
Correct Answer: Welfare Movement in Industries

The New Lanark experiment conducted by Robert Owen is closely associated with the Welfare Movement in Industries. During this experiment, Owen implemented progressive measures to enhance the welfare and well-being of the workers. He focused on improving working conditions, raising the minimum age for child labor, reducing work hours, and making significant efforts to uplift the entire community associated with the factory. By constructing houses and streets, Owen aimed to create an environment that would foster the overall welfare and happiness of the workers. Therefore, the correct answer is C – Welfare Movement in Industries.

Question 4
What is the name of the experiment, which marked the beginning of Labour Welfare? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)
  • A.Hawthorne Experiment
  • B.New Lanark Experiment
  • C.Philadelphia Experiment
  • D.Mule Spinning Department Experiment
Correct Answer: New Lanark Experiment

Robert Owen is called "Father of Personnel Management". During the period 1800 to 1828, he carried out an unprecedented experiment in the group of textile mills at New Lanark in Scotland. Owen improved working conditions in the factory, raised the minimum working age for children, reduced hours of work for employees, and sought to improve the entire community in which his employees lived by building houses and streets and making the community and factory attractive.

Question 5
Which of the following experiments is associated with the welfare movement? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2009)
  • A.Hawthorne Experiment
  • B.New Lanark Experiment
  • C.Ahmedabad Experiment
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: New Lanark Experiment

The New Lanark Experiment, associated with the welfare movement, was conducted by Socialist Robert Owen. Owen's New Lanark mills implemented social and industrial welfare programs, which gained recognition from statesmen and social reformers. He improved housing conditions and influenced the workers to adopt habits of order, cleanliness, and thrift.

 

On the other hand, the Hawthorne experiments were conducted between 1924 and 1932 at the Hawthorne Works in Chicago. Initially focused on lighting and productivity, the experiments expanded to study group behavior and became foundational in the human relations school. The experiments were conducted at Western Electric Company's Hawthorne Works and drew the involvement of the Harvard Business School research team.

 

The Ahmedabad Experiment, described by A. K. Rice in his book "Productivity and Social Organization: The Ahmedabad Experiment 1958," involved the reorganization of weaving in an Indian textile company. The experiment introduced semiautonomous work groups responsible for production and routine maintenance on a group of looms. The concept of a socio-technical system was applied, resulting in significant improvements in output, quality, and work satisfaction.

 

In a follow-up study conducted in 1970, the work organization and performance levels were examined in four locations of the company, including the original sites and two other loom sheds. The study revealed that one of the original sites remained largely unchanged over 16 years, while group working had diminished in a newer automatic loom shed. Regression was also observed in the other sheds studied. The study discussed the differential outcomes and resilience in work organization systems.

 

Therefore, the New Lanark Experiment (Option B) is associated with the welfare movement, as explained above.

Question 6
Who spearheaded the welfare movement during the early industrialization period? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2014)
  • A.Robert Owen
  • B.Robert Katz
  • C.AndrewUre
  • D.SheebhomRowntree
Correct Answer: Robert Owen

It was Robert Owen, who spearheaded the Welfare Movement during the early industrialization period.

 

Robert Owen is called “Father of Personnel Management”. During the period 1800 to 1828, he carried out an unprecedented experiment in the group of textile mills at New Lanark in Scotland. Owen improved working conditions in the factory, raised the minimum working age for children, reduced hours of work for employees, and sought to improve the entire community in which his employees lived by building houses and streets and making the community and factory attractive.

Question 7
Who was the first person to advocate eight hours working day for workers?
  • A.Robert Owen
  • B.John Stuart Mill
  • C.George Elliot
  • D.August Comte
Correct Answer: Robert Owen

Robert Owen was the first person to advocate 8 hours working day for workers.

 

During the Industrial Revolution, companies attempted to maximize the output of their factories by keeping them running as many hours as possible, typically implementing a “sun up to sun down” work-day. Wages were also extremely low, so workers themselves often needed to work these long shifts just to get by, including often sending their children to work in the factories as well, rather than getting them educated. With little representation, education, or options, factory workers also tended to work in horrible working conditions to go along with the bad hours. The typical workday at this time lasted anywhere from 10-18 hours per day, six days a week. This all began to change in the 19th century.

 

The first to suggest an 8-hour work day for everyone was a British man by the name of Robert Owen, who was also one of the founders of socialism. Owen felt that the work day should be divided into thirds, with workers getting equal time to themselves and to sleep as they do for work.

Question 8
Management theories help organizations to focus, communicate, and evolve. Using management theory in the workplace allows leadership to focus on their main goals. When a management style or theory is implemented, it automatically streamlines the top priorities for the organization. Management theory also allows us to better communicate with people we work with which in turn allows us to work more efficiently. By understanding management theory, basic assumptions about management styles and goals can be assumed and can save time during daily interactions and meetings within an organization.Theories can only reach so far, and management theories are no exception. There is no such thing as a one-size-fits-all management theory. What may work for one organization may not be relevant for another. Therefore.whenone theory does not fit a particular situation.itis important to explore the option of developing a new theory that would lead in a new, more applicable direction. While some theories can stand the test of time, other theories may grow to be irrelevant and new theories will develop in their place.From the late 1700s through the early 1900s.theIndustrial Revolution brought extraordinary change to the workplace and forever transformed the way companies operate. The Industrial Revolution brought better and faster technology allowing companies to perform more efficiently than ever before and giving them the ability to dramatically increase their output. In order to meet demand, company leadership had to ensure their employees were productive.Given below are two statements:Statement I:Management is the ultimate tool for achieving business goals.Statement II:It was management only which initiated the industrial revolution.In the light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are true
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are false
  • C.Statement I is true but Statement II is false
  • D.Statement I is false but Statement II is true
Correct Answer: Statement I is true but Statement II is false

The answer can be deduced from the following lines of the passage: 

 

“Using management theory in the workplace allows leadership to focus on their main goals.”

 

Hence, the statement I is correct. But there is nothing as statement II being stated in the passage.

Question 9
Management theories help organizations to focus, communicate, and evolve. Using management theory in the workplace allows leadership to focus on their main goals. When a management style or theory is implemented, it automatically streamlines the top priorities for the organization. Management theory also allows us to better communicate with people we work with which in turn allows us to work more efficiently. By understanding management theory, basic assumptions about management styles and goals can be assumed and can save time during daily interactions and meetings within an organization.Theories can only reach so far, and management theories are no exception. There is no such thing as a one-size-fits-all management theory. What may work for one organization may not be relevant for another. Therefore.whenone theory does not fit a particular situation.itis important to explore the option of developing a new theory that would lead in a new, more applicable direction. While some theories can stand the test of time, other theories may grow to be irrelevant and new theories will develop in their place.From the late 1700s through the early 1900s.theIndustrial Revolution brought extraordinary change to the workplace and forever transformed the way companies operate. The Industrial Revolution brought better and faster technology allowing companies to perform more efficiently than ever before and giving them the ability to dramatically increase their output. In order to meet demand, company leadership had to ensure their employees were productive.What helps leadership to focus on their main goal?Management theories2. Organizational structure3. Inter-personal relations4. Effective HR policies5. Government DirectivesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:

  • B.2, 3 and 4 only
  • C.1 and 2 only
  • D.1 only

“Using management theory in the workplace allows leadership to focus on their main goals.”

Question 10
