Management theories help organizations to focus, communicate, and evolve. Using management theory in the workplace allows leadership to focus on their main goals. When a management style or theory is implemented, it automatically streamlines the top priorities for the organization. Management theory also allows us to better communicate with people we work with which in turn allows us to work more efficiently. By understanding management theory, basic assumptions about management styles and goals can be assumed and can save time during daily interactions and meetings within an organization.Theories can only reach so far, and management theories are no exception. There is no such thing as a one-size-fits-all management theory. What may work for one organization may not be relevant for another. Therefore.whenone theory does not fit a particular situation.itis important to explore the option of developing a new theory that would lead in a new, more applicable direction. While some theories can stand the test of time, other theories may grow to be irrelevant and new theories will develop in their place.From the late 1700s through the early 1900s.theIndustrial Revolution brought extraordinary change to the workplace and forever transformed the way companies operate. The Industrial Revolution brought better and faster technology allowing companies to perform more efficiently than ever before and giving them the ability to dramatically increase their output. In order to meet demand, company leadership had to ensure their employees were productive.In the paragraph, what is meant by “There is no such thing as a non-size fits all management theory”.1. Management theories keeps on changing.2. There are different theories for different situations.3. A business can’t grow without management theories.4. Management theories are non-scientific.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1, 2 and 3 only
  • B.2, 3 and 4 only
  • C.3 and 4 only
  • D.1 and 2 only
Correct Answer: 1 and 2 only

The answer can be deduced from the following lines of the passage: 

 

“There is no such thing as a one-size-fits-all management theory. What may work for one organization may not be relevant for another. Therefore. when one theory does not fit a particular situation. it is important to explore the option of developing a new theory that would lead in a new, more applicable direction. While some theories can stand the test of time, other theories may grow to be irrelevant and new theories will develop in their place.”

Question 11
Who among the following is known for application of Psychology to industry and management? (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)
  • A.Thomas Peters
  • B.Chester Barnard
  • C.Mary Parker Follett
  • D.Hugo Munsterberg
Correct Answer: Hugo Munsterberg

Hugo Munsterberg was a German-American psychologist who made significant contributions to the field of applied psychology. He is often considered one of the pioneers of industrial-organizational psychology. Munsterberg's work focused on the application of psychological principles to various aspects of industry, including personnel selection, employee motivation, and organizational behavior. He emphasized the importance of understanding human behavior and psychological processes in the workplace to improve efficiency and productivity.

Question 12
Who is the champion of the ‘Welfare movement’ propagated in mid-19thcentury? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2012)
  • A.Frederick Winslow Taylor
  • B.AndrewUre
  • C.SheebhomRownlvee
  • D.Robert Owen
Correct Answer: Robert Owen

The labor welfare movement began in early year of industrial revolution with the support of philanthropists such as Robert Owen; according to him at least provision of minimum standard of welfare is essential for the workers as at that time mass production was main concern for the factory owners, they exploited the workers, working conditions were also poor.

Question 13
Who argued that money spent on improving labour was one of the best investments that business executives could make? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2022)
  • A.Hugo Munsterberg
  • B.Elton Mayo
  • C.Charles Babbage
  • D.Robert Owen
Correct Answer: Robert Owen

The given statement was argued by Robert Owen. He argued that money spent on improving labour was one of the best investments that business executives could make. He claimed that showing concern for employees both was profitable for management and would relieve human misery.

 

Robert Owen (1771-1858) was an early industrialist. He is perhaps best known for his model textile factory and village at New Lanark in Scotland. He is the founder of utopian socialism and the cooperative movement. He strove to improve factory working conditions, promoted experimental socialistic communities, and sought a more collective approach to child rearing, including government control of education.

Quiz Attempt #118942

Total Questions: 31
Question 1
Frederic W Taylor is acknowledged as the father of scientificmanagement .What is his major contribution to management.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.Theory of bureaucracy
  • B.Identified characteristics of companies he considered excellent
  • C.Application ofpsychologicalin industry and management
  • D.How to raise productivity through greater efficiency in production and increased pay for workers
Correct Answer: How to raise productivity through greater efficiency in production and increased pay for workers

Frederick W. Taylor is indeed considered the father of scientific management. His major contribution was developing principles and methods aimed at increasing productivity and efficiency in industrial settings. Taylor advocated for the systematic analysis of work processes to identify the most efficient ways of performing tasks. He also emphasized the importance of providing appropriate training and incentives to workers to motivate them to perform at their best. Overall, Taylor's ideas revolutionized management practices by introducing scientific methods to improve productivity and worker performance.

Question 2
Who coined the term ‘scientific management’? (UGC NET HRM Aug 2016)
  • A.Frederick Winslow Taylor
  • B.Henry R. Towne
  • C.Louis D. Brandies
  • D.Henry L. Gantt
Correct Answer: Louis D. Brandies

While the terms “scientific management” and “Taylorism” are commonly treated as synonymous, the work of Frederick Taylor marks only the first form of scientific management. But Taylor's own names for his approach initially included "shop management" and "process management". It was Louis Brandeis, who popularized the term “scientific management” in 1910.

Question 3
‘Case of Schmidt’ is associated with which School of Management thought?
  • A.Human Relations School
  • B.Behavioural School
  • C.Systems Approach
  • D.Scientific Management
Correct Answer: Scientific Management

F.W. Taylor used the example of Schmidt at the Bethlehem Steel Company to test his theories. His book "Principles of Scientific Management" had story of “Schmidt,” a stocky Pennsylvania German who was a pig-iron loader at Bethlehem Steel. Schmidt loaded about 12 tons of iron pigs each day. Using Taylor’s principles, “scientific managers” raised Schmidt’s output to 48 tons per day and raised his daily wages from $1.15 to $1.85.

Question 4
Who has called the scientific management a ‘rabblehypothesis’? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2012)
  • A.Peter F. Drucker
  • B.Elton Mayo
  • C.Douglas McGregor
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Elton Mayo

Option B is the correct answer.

 

The word rabble means crowd or mob and Rabble hypothesis takes the view of men being a crowd of individuals interested in their individual interest. Such a negative view of man by Taylor’s Scientific Management was called rabble hypotheses. Elton Mayo puts the following points to refute the rabble theory.

(i) postulating that it was collaboration with others, not competition among a disorganized horde, that was important;

(ii) stating that all individuals acted to protect their group status and not their self-interest; and

(iii) repeating the Hawthorne findings that thinking was guided more by sentiment than by logic.

 

In the words of Elton Mayo:

“We have learned how to destroy scores of thousands of human beings in a moment of time; we do not know how systematically to set about the task of inducing various groups and nations to collaborate in the tasks of civilization. It is not the atomic bomb that will destroy civilization. But civilized society can destroy itself …… if it fails to understand intelligently and to control the aids and deterrents to cooperation.”

Question 5
Examine the following statements about Scientific Management and identify those which are true and false. (UGC NET HRM Jan 2017)a. The term ‘Scientific Management’ was not coined by Frederick Winslow Taylor.b. HenryR. Towne’s ‘Engineer as an economist’ influenced Taylor’s ideas.c. ‘Shop Management’ embodies ‘Therbligs’.d. LouisD. Brandies heard the case filed against Taylor’s Scientific Management by Trade Unions.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a, b, c are true and d is false.
  • B.a, b, d are true and c is false.
  • C.a, b are true and c, d are false.
  • D.a, c are true and b, d are false.
Correct Answer: a, b, d are true and c is false.

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Statement a - The term 'Scientific Management' was not coined by Frederick Winslow Taylor.

While the terms “scientific management” and “Taylorism” are commonly treated as synonymous, the work of Frederick Taylor marks only the first form of scientific management. But Taylor's own names for his approach initially included "shop management" and "process management". It was Louis Brandeis, who popularized the term “scientific management” in 1910.

 

Statement b - Henry R. Towne's 'Engineer as an economist' influenced Taylor’s ideas.

This statement is true. Henry R. Towne, the President of the Yale and Towne Manufacturing Company, played a significant role in establishing modern management methods. His paper, 'The Engineer as an Economist,' delivered in 1886, likely inspired Taylor to dedicate his work to Scientific Management. Thus, Statement b is true.

 

Statement c - 'Shop Management' embodies 'Therbligs.'

This statement is false. 'Therbligs' are 18 elemental motions used in the study of motion economy and time and motion studies. The term 'Therbligs' was coined by Frank Bunker Gilbreth and Lillian Moller Gilbreth, not related to 'Shop Management.' Therefore, Statement c is false.

 

Statement d - Louis D. Brandeis heard the case filed against Taylor's Scientific Management by Trade Unions.

This statement is true. In 1911, Louis D. Brandeis, who later became a Supreme Court Justice, introduced the testimony of Harrington Emerson, a leader in the Scientific Management movement, in a case before the Interstate Commerce Commission. Brandeis was representing a group of shippers protesting the railroad's request for an increase in freight rates. Brandeis coined the term 'scientific management' in 1911. Thus, Statement d is true.

 

Based on the analysis above, we can conclude that the correct answer is Option B - a, b, d are true and c is false.

Question 6
The concepts of ‘human engineering’ and ‘ergonomics’ are advanced by which school of management thought? (UGC NET HRM Sep 2013)
  • A.Quantitative School
  • B.Human Relations School
  • C.Behavioural School
  • D.Scientific Management School
Correct Answer: Scientific Management School

Human-factors engineering, also called ergonomics or human engineering, science dealing with the application of information on physical and psychological characteristics to the design of devices and systems for human use.

 

Frederick Taylor's scientific management theory can be seen in nearly all modern manufacturing firms and many other types of businesses. His imprint can be found in production planning, production control, process design, quality control, cost accounting, and even ergonomics. If you understand the principles of scientific management, you will be able to understand how manufacturers produce their goods and manage their employees. You will also understand the importance of quantitative analysis, or the analysis of data and numbers to improve production effectiveness and efficiency.

Question 7
Time and Motion Study was propounded by: (UGC NET HRM Sep 2013)
  • A.Louis D. Brandies
  • B.Frank B.Gilberth
  • C.Elton Mayo
  • D.HenryGnatt
Correct Answer: Frank B.Gilberth

Option B is the correct answer.

 

Time and Motion Study, also known as work measurement or time study, was propounded by Frank B. Gilbreth. He was an American engineer and industrial psychologist who, along with his wife Lillian Moller Gilbreth, made significant contributions to the field of scientific management.

 

Time and Motion Study is a systematic approach used to analyze and improve work processes by breaking them down into individual tasks and studying the time required to perform each task. The goal is to identify and eliminate unnecessary motions, reduce inefficiencies, and optimize productivity.

 

Frank B. Gilbreth, along with his wife, conducted extensive research and experiments to study the movements and actions involved in performing various tasks. They developed the concept of "Therbligs," which are 18 elemental motions used in time and motion analysis. By meticulously observing workers and their movements, they aimed to identify the most efficient methods of performing tasks and eliminate any wasteful or non-value-added actions.

Question 8
Max Weber developed a theory of: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)
  • A.Autocratic Management
  • B.Democratic Management
  • C.Bureaucratic Management
  • D.Free Style Management
Correct Answer: Bureaucratic Management

Max Weber (1864-1920), a German sociologist introduced the theory of Bureaucracy, also known as Theory of Impersonal Management. His major contribution to the theory is the concept of authority structure and its inter-se relationship.

 

Salient points of the Bureaucratic Model are as under:

(a) Hierarchy of authority exists in the organization, which involves superior-subordinate relationship and chain of command.

(b) Division of work based on competence and functional foremanship.

(c) System of policy, rules, and regulations are necessary to regulate subordinate behaviour and to ensure rationality, objectivity, discipline and control.

(d) In bureaucratic model, rule of law exists that leads to impersonal behaviour of employees. Relations are based on position in the hierarchy.

(e) Weber suggests standardization of methods, systems, processes, job contents and tools for smooth operation.

(f) Selection and promotion of employees should be based on competence.

(g) Bureaucracy recognizes legal power derived from the official position held by an individual.

Question 9
Consider the following.Assertion ‘A’:According to Taylor, one best way of doing each task leads to increase in productivity in organization.Reason ‘R’:It was the management responsibility alone to find out this one best way.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
  • B.A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A.
  • C.A is true but R is false.
  • D.A is false but R is true.
Correct Answer: A is true but R is false.

A is correct but R is incorrect.

 

The correct answer is Option C - A is true but R is false.

 

Assertion ‘A’ states that according to Taylor, there is one best way of doing each task, which leads to an increase in productivity in the organization. This assertion is true and aligns with Taylor's principles of Scientific Management. Taylor believed in studying work processes and finding the most efficient methods to perform tasks. He emphasized the concept of standardization and believed that by identifying and implementing the one best way of performing a task, productivity could be improved.

 

However, Reason ‘R’ states that it was the management responsibility alone to find out this one best way. This reason is false. Taylor's principles emphasized the need for collaboration and cooperation between management and workers. According to Taylor, the responsibility for finding and implementing the one best way of performing tasks rested with both management and workers. Taylor advocated for scientific analysis and experimentation to determine the most efficient methods, and he believed that management and workers should work together to implement these methods.

Question 10
The classical theorists favoured organization based on: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2012)
  • A.Civilian model
  • B.Strategic model
  • C.Military model
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Military model

Option C is the correct answer.

 

The classical theorists, in the context of organization, favored the organization based on the military model. The classical school of thought in management, which emerged during the late 19th and early 20th centuries, emphasized principles and practices that were often inspired by military organizations. This approach to organization and management drew upon the hierarchical structure, chain of command, and centralized decision-making commonly found in military settings.

 

The military model of organization, also known as the command-and-control model, is characterized by a top-down approach to management. In this model, authority and power are concentrated at the top of the organizational hierarchy, and decisions flow down through various levels of management to be executed by employees at the lower levels. The focus is on maintaining discipline, clear lines of authority, and efficient coordination of activities.

 

Classical theorists such as Henri Fayol and Frederick Winslow Taylor advocated for principles and practices that reflected the military model. Fayol's principles of management, such as unity of command, scalar chain, and centralization, were aligned with the hierarchical structure and authority distribution seen in military organizations. Taylor's scientific management approach emphasized the need for standardized procedures, clear division of labor, and top-down control, similar to the military model.

Question 11
Which of the following principles of management was not given by Fayol? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2012)
  • A.Unity of direction
  • B.Subordination of individual interest to common interest
  • C.Stability of tenure
  • D.Standardization
Correct Answer: Standardization

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Henry Fayol has given 14 principles of Theory of General and Administrative Management viz. Division of Work, Authority and responsibility, Discipline, Unity of Command, Unity of Direction, Subordination of Individual Interest to General Interest, Remuneration, Centralization vs Decentralization, Scalar Chain, Order, Equity, Stability of Tenure of personnel, Initiative and Espirit de Corps.

 

The principle of Standardization was given by F. W. Taylor.

Question 12
Which of the following is/are NOT a part of classical approach to management? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2014)
  • A.Scientific Management
  • B.Administrative Management
  • C.Decision Theory
  • D.Bureaucratic Organization
Correct Answer: Decision Theory

Option C – Decision Theory is not a part of the classical approach to management.

 

The classical approach to management includes three main components: scientific management, administrative management, and bureaucratic organization. Decision Theory, on the other hand, is not traditionally considered as a part of the classical approach.

 

Scientific management, as proposed by Frederick Winslow Taylor, focuses on improving efficiency through systematic analysis and optimization of work processes. It emphasizes standardization, specialization, and simplification of tasks.

 

Administrative management, developed by Henri Fayol, emphasizes the administrative functions of planning, organizing, commanding, coordinating, and controlling within an organization. It focuses on principles such as unity of command, scalar chain, and division of labor.

 

Bureaucratic organization, as theorized by Max Weber, emphasizes the formal structure, rules, and procedures within an organization. It highlights the importance of hierarchy, clear division of labor, and impersonal relationships based on rules and regulations.

 

On the other hand, Decision Theory is a broader concept that deals with the study of decision-making processes and techniques. It focuses on how individuals and groups make decisions, considering factors such as rationality, uncertainty, and risk. While decision-making is a crucial aspect of management, Decision Theory is not specifically associated with the classical approach to management.

Question 13
Match the following: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2013)List I (Thinker)a. Mary Parker Follettb. Henry Fayolc. F.W. Taylord. Gilbreth and TaylorList II (Principles)i. Co-ordinationii. Elements of Managementiii. Scientific methodsiv. Quantitative MeasurementSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.a-i, b -ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • C.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
  • D.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-i, b -ii, c-iii, d-iv

a. Mary Parker Follett - Co-ordination

Mary Parker Follett gave four main Principles of Coordination. These four principles of co-ordination are called are Follett's Principles of Coordination as described below:

 

1. Principle of Early Stage: According to this principle, coordination must start at an early stage in the management process. It must start during the planning stage. This will result in making the best plans and implementing these plans with success. If coordination is started early only then all the management functions will be performed successfully. Thus by initiating proper coordination the organisation will achieve all its objectives easily and quickly.

 

2. Principle of Continuity: According to this principle, coordination must be a continuous process. It must not be a one-time activity. The process of coordination must begin when the organisation starts, and it must continue until the organisation exists. Coordination must be done continuously during the management process. It must be done during planning, organising, directing and controlling.

 

3. Principle of Direct Contact: According to this principle, all managers must have a Direct Contact with their subordinates. This will result in good relations between the manager and their subordinates. This is because direct contact helps to avoid misunderstandings, misinterpretations and disputes between managers and subordinates. It enables the managers to coordinate all the different activities of their subordinates effectively and efficiently.

 

4. Principle of Reciprocal Relations: The decisions and actions of all the people (i.e. of all managers and employees) and departments of the organisation are inter-related. So, the decisions and actions of one person or department will affect all other persons and departments in the organisation. Therefore, before taking any decision or action all managers must first find out the effect of that decision or action on other persons and departments in the organisation. This is called the Principle of Reciprocal Relations. Co-ordination will be successful only if this principle is followed properly.

 

b. Henry Fayol - Elements of Management

Henri Fayol was the first person to identify elements or functions of management in his classic 1916 book Administration Industrielle et Generale. Fayol was the managing director of a large French coal-mining firm and based his book largely on his experiences as a practitioner of management. Fayol defined five functions, or elements of management: Planning, Organizing, Commanding, Coordinating, and Controlling. Fayol argued that these functions were universal, in the sense that all managers performed them in the course of their jobs, whether the managers worked in business, military, government, religious, or philanthropic undertakings.

 

a. Planning is forecasting future conditions, setting objectives, and developing means to attain objectives. Fayol recognized that effective planning must also take into account unexpected contingencies that might arise and did not advocate rigid and inflexible plans. 

 

b. Organizing is provision for the structuring of activities and relationships within the firm and also the recruiting, evaluation, and training of personnel. 

 

c. Commanding is managerial function concerned the personal supervision of subordinates and involved inspiring them to put forth unified effort to achieve objectives. Fayol emphasized the importance of managers understanding the people who worked for them, setting a good example, treating subordinates in a manner consistent with firm policy, delegating, and communicating through meetings and conferences. 

 

d. Coordination is harmonizing all of the various activities of the firm. Most later experts did not retain Fayol's coordination function as a separate function of management but regarded it as a necessary component of all the other management functions. 

 

e. Control function is ensuring that everything occurs within the parameters of the plan and accompanying principles. The purpose of control was to identify deviations from objectives and plans and to take corrective action. 

 

c. F.W. Taylor - Scientific methods

Frederick Winslow Taylor, the acknowledged 'Father' of scientific management was a pre classical contributor. Taylor was the founder of a system that stated the relationship of workers and managers to the realm of new science/technology. Scientific management is the approach emphasizing production efficiencies by scientifically searching for the 'one best way' to do each job. 

 

d. Gilbreth and Taylor - Quantitative measurement

Frank Bunker Gilbreth is known as the disciple of Taylor who concentrated his efforts on Motion Study and Fatigue Study which is an extension of scientific management as propounded by F. W. Taylor. His in depth analysis for the 'best method' resulted in "Therblig's" which identified 17 basic elements in completion of a task. Gilbreth's published work included Motion Study (1911), Primer of Scientific Management (1912) and Fatigue Study (1916). Lillian Gilbreth assisted her husband, Frank Gilbreth in publishing his works. As a psychologist, she added psychological implications of management. Her works include The Psychology of Management (1920), The quest of the one best way (1918) and The Foreman and Manpower Management (1922). She is referred as "First Lady of Management".

Question 14
Who identified the basic elements of work known as ‘therbligs’? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2014)
  • A.Henry L. Gantt
  • B.Frank B. Gilbreth
  • C.F.W. Taylor
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: Frank B. Gilbreth

Therbligs are 18 kinds of elemental motions used in the study of motion economy in the workplace. A workplace task is analysed by recording each of the therblig units for a process, with the results used for optimization of manual labour by eliminating unneeded movements. The word therblig was the creation of Frank Bunker Gilbreth and Lillian Moller Gilbreth, American industrial psychologists who invented the field of time and motion study.

Question 15
Taylor’s differential piece work plan provides that: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)
  • A.Alllaborersshould be assigned different amount of work.
  • B.Alllaborersshould be put in different time-period.
  • C.Those who produce above standard should receive higher wages than those producing below standard.
  • D.Payment should be the same on a fixed standard.
Correct Answer: Those who produce above standard should receive higher wages than those producing below standard.

F. W. Taylor, popularly known as the father of Scientific Management, assumed that through time and motion study it is possible to fix a standard time for doing a particular task. To encourage the workers to complete the work within the standard time, Taylor advocated two piece rates, so that if a worker performs the work within or less than the standard time, he is pad a higher piece rate, and if he does not complete the work within the standard time, he is given a lower piece rate.

 

The underlying principle of this system is to penalize a slow worker by paying him a low piece rate for low production and to reward an efficient worker by giving him a higher piece rate for a higher production. Taylor was of the view that an inefficient worker should have no place in the organization and he should be compelled to leave the organization by paying him a low piece rate for low production.

 

Thus, if the standard production has been fixed at 8 units per day of 8 hours (taking normal piece rate as Re 10), the higher piece rate for 8 units or beyond may be Rs 12 per unit and the lower rate for an output of less than 8 units per day, may be Rs. 8 per unit.

 

Hence, Taylor decided to give a large reward to those who would complete the work within or less than the standard time and much less wages to those who would not complete the job within the standard time. The system is very harsh to the inefficient workers because they earn much less wages on account of lower output and lower rate. Moreover, minimum wages are not guaranteed under this method.

Question 16
F.W. Taylor called “The Military type of Foreman” to: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.Unity of Command
  • B.Span of Control
  • C.Delegated Legislature
  • D.Department
Correct Answer: Unity of Command

F.W. Taylor called "The Military type of Foreman" to the principle of Unity of Command. The principle of Unity of Command states that each employee in an organization should have only one direct supervisor or manager to whom they report. This principle ensures that there is a clear and unambiguous line of authority and responsibility within the organization.

 

Taylor's rejection of the principle of Unity of Command was based on the idea of functional foremanship, where a worker would receive orders from multiple functional foremen specializing in different aspects of the work. However, the principle of Unity of Command remains an essential part of organizational theory and practice, emphasizing the need for clear communication and avoiding confusion caused by multiple authorities issuing conflicting orders to employees.

 

While some critics argue that the principle of Unity of Command may not be practical in large organizations with numerous departments, it is still considered a crucial and indispensable principle in the study of organizational management and public administration. It ensures accountability, effective decision-making, and streamlined communication within the organization.

Question 17
Match the following:List – I(a) To check the quality of work.(b) To see that work is completed in time.(c) To check absenteeism of workers.(d) To issue instruction regarding method of workList – II1. Speed boss2. Inspection3. Instruction clerk4. Shop discipline
  • A.a-3, b-2, c-1, d-4
  • B.a-2, b-1, c-4, d-3
  • C.a-2, b-1, c-3, d-4
  • D.a-4, b-3, c-1, d-2
Correct Answer: a-2, b-1, c-4, d-3

The correct answer is (B) 2 1 4 3.

 

Explanation:

The list of techniques of Scientific Management given by F.W. Taylor and the corresponding activities are as follows:

 

(a) To check the quality of work - Inspection

(b) To see that work is completed in time - Speed boss

(c) To check absenteeism of workers - Shop discipline

(d) To issue instruction regarding the method of work - Instruction clerk

 

The concept of "Functional Foremanship" in Scientific Management involves dividing the responsibilities of a traditional foreman into specialized functions or roles, each led by a different person. The list provided in List II corresponds to these functional roles as follows:

 

(1) Speed boss - To see that work is completed in time.

(2) Inspection - To check the quality of work.

(3) Instruction clerk - To issue instructions regarding the method of work.

(4) Shop discipline - To check absenteeism of workers.

Question 18
Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct about scalar chain principle as given by Fayol? (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2016)(a) Each communication, going up or down, must flow through each position in the line authority.(b) Chain of communication cannot be broken under any circumstances.
  • A.Only (a) is correct.
  • B.Only (b) is correct.
  • C.Neither (a) nor (b) is correct.
  • D.Both (a) and (b) are correct.
Correct Answer: Only (a) is correct.

The correct answer is (A) Only (a) is correct.

 

The statement (a) "Each communication, going up or down, must flow through each position in the line authority" is correct about the scalar chain principle as given by Fayol. The scalar chain principle emphasizes the formal line of authority in an organization, which moves from the highest level of authority to the lowest level in a straight line. This chain specifies the route through which information and communication should flow within the organization.

 

In a scalar chain, every communication, whether going up to higher levels of management or down to lower levels, must follow the established chain of command. This ensures clear communication of orders from superiors and feedback from subordinates, preventing confusion and misinterpretation of information.

 

However, the statement (b) "Chain of communication cannot be broken under any circumstances" is not correct. While the scalar chain provides a clear and formal line of communication, it is recognized that in some emergency situations or critical scenarios, the chain of communication can be bypassed for the sake of expediency. Fayol introduced the concept of "Gang Plank" to address this issue. The Gang Plank allows two executives at the same hierarchical level in different departments to communicate directly in urgent situations, bypassing the formal scalar chain temporarily.

Question 19
Which of the following statements relating to Henry Fayol are correct? (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)Statement I:Authority and responsibility are related and former arises from latter.Statement II:Espiritde Corps is an extension of the principle of unity of command.Statement III:Unity of command means only one command at a time.Statement IV:There are fourteen basic principles identified by Henry Fayol.
  • A.Statements I, II and IV
  • B.Statements II and III
  • C.Statements I and IV
  • D.Statements II and IV
Correct Answer: Statements II and IV

The correct answer is (D) Statements II and IV.

 

Statement I: "Authority and responsibility are related and former arises from latter."

This statement is incorrect. Authority and responsibility are related concepts, but it is responsibility that arises from authority, not the other way around. Authority is the right to give orders and make decisions, while responsibility is the obligation to perform assigned tasks and be accountable for the outcomes. In a formal organizational structure, authority is delegated to individuals along with corresponding responsibilities.

 

Statement II: "Espirit de Corps is an extension of the principle of unity of command."

This statement is correct. Espirit de Corps is a principle introduced by Henry Fayol that emphasizes the need for teamwork and harmonious relations among employees. It can be seen as an extension of the principle of unity of command, which states that each employee should receive orders from only one superior. By promoting teamwork and unity among employees, Espirit de Corps enhances the effectiveness of the organization.

 

Statement III: "Unity of command means only one command at a time."

This statement is incorrect. Unity of command does not mean that an employee can receive only one command at a time. Instead, it means that each employee should have only one direct supervisor or superior to whom they report. This principle ensures clarity in communication, accountability, and avoids conflicting instructions.

 

Statement IV: "There are fourteen basic principles identified by Henry Fayol."

This statement is correct. Henry Fayol identified and formulated 14 principles of management that he believed could guide managers in effectively running their organizations. These principles cover various aspects of management, including division of work, authority, discipline, unity of command, unity of direction, remuneration, centralization vs. decentralization, scalar chain, order, equity, stability of tenure, initiative, and Espirit de Corps.

Question 20
Who has given ‘fourteen Principles of Management’? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2012)
  • A.Barnard
  • B.Henry Fayol
  • C.F.W. Taylor
  • D.Flemming
Correct Answer: Henry Fayol

Henri Fayol, who was the first person to identify elements or functions of management in his classic 1916 book Administration Industrielle et Generale. Fayol was the managing director of a large French coal-mining firm and based his book largely on his experiences as a practitioner of management. Fayol defined five functions, or elements of management: Planning, Organizing, Commanding, Coordinating, and Controlling. 

 

Henry Fayol has given 14 principles of Theory of General and Administrative Management viz. Division of Work, Authority and responsibility, Discipline, Unity of Command, Unity of Direction, Subordination of Individual Interest to General Interest, Remuneration, centralization vs Decentralization, Scalar Chain, Order, Equity, Stability of Tenure of personnel, Initiative and Espirit de Corps. These principles are described below:

(i) Division of work - In practice, employees are specialized in different areas and they have different skills. Different levels of expertise can be distinguished within the knowledge areas (from generalist to specialist). Personal and professional developments support this. According to Henri Fayol specialization promotes efficiency of the workforce and increases productivity. In addition, the specialization of the workforce increases their accuracy and speed. This is applicable to both technical and managerial activities.

 

(ii) Authority - According to Henri Fayol, the accompanying power or authority gives the management the right to give orders to the subordinates.

 

(iii) Discipline - This third principle of the 14 principles of management is about obedience. It is often a part of the core values of a mission and vision in the form of good conduct and respectful interactions 14 principles of management

 

(iv) Unity of command - Every employee should receive orders from only one superior or behalf of the superior.

 

(v) Unity of direction - Each group of organizational activities that have the same objective should be directed by one manager using one plan for achievement of one common goal.

 

(vi) Subordination of Individual Interest - The interests of any one employee or group of employees should not take precedence over the interests of the organization as a whole.

 

(vii) Remuneration - All Workers must be paid a fair wage for their services.

 

(viii) Centralization and Decentralization - When the power to take decision rests with the top management it is called as ‘Centralization’. When the power to take decision is given to the person performing the job it is called as ‘Decentralization’. Fayol is of the opinion that there should be a proper balance between centralization and decentralization. An organization must not be completely centralized or decentralized, there should be a match between the two depending upon the size, nature and location of business. The top management must keep the authority to take important decisions of the organization but adequate authority must be delegated to the lower level employees to take the department level decisions. This will facilitate the proper and timely functioning in the organization.

 

(ix) Scalar chain - The line of authority from top management to the lowest ranks represents the scalar chain. Communications should follow this chain.

 

(x) Order - This principle is concerned with systematic arrangement of men, machine, material etc. There should be a specific place for all physical resources in an organization to facilitate smooth working and avoid wastage of resources. It states “A proper place for everything and everything at its proper place”.

 

(xi) Equity - Managers should be kind and fair to their subordinates.

 

(xii) Stability of tenure of personnel - High employee turnover is inefficient. Management should provide orderly personnel planning and ensure that replacements are available to fill vacancies.

 

(xiii) Initiative - Employees who are allowed to originate and carry out plans will exert high levels of effort.

 

(iv) Esprit de corps - Promoting team spirit will build harmony and unity within the organization.

Question 21
The classical organization theory treats organization as a/an: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.Open system
  • B.Closed system
  • C.Technical system
  • D.Macro system
Correct Answer: Closed system

The classical organization theory treats organization as a (B) Closed system.

 

The classical organization theory, represented by the scientific management approach of Frederick Taylor, the bureaucratic approach of Max Weber, and the administrative theory of Henri Fayol, views organizations as closed systems. A closed system in organizational theory refers to a model where the organization is considered as a self-contained entity that is relatively isolated from its external environment.

 

In the classical perspective, organizations are seen as machines where human beings are considered as components or resources. The focus is on achieving efficiency and effectiveness within the internal operations of the organization. The emphasis is on specialization, standardization, and hierarchy to achieve organizational goals.

 

Closed systems are characterized by a lack of significant interaction with the external environment. Classical organization theory assumes a stable and predictable environment where organizations can function without much external influence. The management practices in this approach are designed to tightly control the internal processes to achieve maximum efficiency.

 

However, it is important to note that the classical organization theory has been criticized for its narrow focus on internal efficiency and its disregard for the dynamic and unpredictable nature of the external environment. Modern organizational theories, such as the contingency theory and the systems theory, have emerged to address the limitations of the classical approach and recognize the importance of considering the external environment and its impact on the organization. These modern theories view organizations as open systems, which interact and adapt to changes in their environment to survive and thrive.

Question 22
The number of subordinates a superior can effectively handle is called: (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Organizing people
  • B.Span of control
  • C.Direction
  • D.Coordination
Correct Answer: Span of control

The number of subordinates a superior can effectively handle is called Span of Control.

 

Span of Control means the number of subordinates a manager can control. Classical thinkers specified numbers at different levels which can be effectively supervised by a superior. A manager cannot exercise proper control if the number of subordinates increases beyond a certain figure, on the other hand if the number is less than his capacity and knowledge cannot be fully utilized.

 

The span of management is related to the horizontal levels of the organization structure. There is a wide and a narrow span of management. With the wider span, there will be less hierarchical levels, and thus, the organizational structure would be flatter. Whereas, with the narrow span, the hierarchical levels increases, hence the organizational structure would be tall.

 

The capacity of a person to supervise and control a large number of persons is also limited on account of time available at his disposal to supervise them. The span of control would be generally narrow at the higher levels of management because top managers have to spend their major time on planning, organizing, directing and controlling and the time available at their disposal for supervision will be lesser. At lower levels of management, this span would obliviously be wide because they have to devote lesser time on such other activities.

Question 23
Who is father of Administrative Management Theory? (UGC NET Management Dec 2012)
  • A.Max Weber
  • B.FrankGilbraith
  • C.Henry Fayol
  • D.Henry Gantt
Correct Answer: Henry Fayol

Henry Fayol, a French mining engineer and management theorist, is widely regarded as the father of Administrative Management Theory. He is best known for his work on the 14 principles of management and the five functions of management. Fayol's ideas and principles have significantly influenced the development of modern management theories and practices.

 

Fayol's work on administrative management was published in his book "General and Industrial Management" in 1916. In this book, he outlined the functions of management, which are planning, organizing, commanding, coordinating, and controlling. He also emphasized the importance of unity of command, division of work, scalar chain, and other principles that are still relevant in management practices today.

 

Fayol's contributions laid the foundation for the development of classical management theory, which includes the works of other management pioneers like Frederick Taylor and Max Weber. His ideas continue to be studied and applied in management education and organizational management to this day.

Question 24
During his days at Midvale Steel Company F.W. Taylor saw that employees soldiering – deliberately working at a pace slower than their capabilities. He identified that, worker indulge in soldiering primarily for the following reasons:(UGC NET Management Jun 2012)
  • A.Fear of losing jobs if they increase their output.
  • B.Faulty wage systems.
  • C.Out-dated methods of working
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

F. W. Taylor, by developing specific principles of scientific management, in 1911 became the father of scientific management. He started his experiments with the concept in 1878 at Midvale Steel Co. During his days at Midvale Steel Company F.W. Taylor saw that employees soldiering – deliberately working at a pace slower than their capabilities. He identified that, worker indulge in soldiering primarily for three reasons as under:

a) fear of losing jobs if they increase their output

b) faulty wage systems

c) outdated methods of working

 

For eliminating this problem, Taylor developed the principles of scientific management, emphasizing mainly on five important issues:

1) attain organized knowledge rather relying on rule of thumb

2) obtain harmony in group action

3) achieve cooperation

4) work for maximum output rather than restricted output

5) develop all workers both for their self-development and organizational prosperity

Question 25
Who coined the term Scientific Management? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2012)
  • A.Louis D. Brandies
  • B.F. W. Taylor
  • C.Douglas Mc Gregor
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Louis D. Brandies

Louis Brandeis, who was an active propagandist of Taylorism coined the term scientific management in the course of his argument for the Eastern Rate Case, which Taylor used in the title of his monograph The Principles of Scientific Management, published in 1911. His approach is also often referred to, as Taylor's Principles, or frequently disparagingly, as Taylorism.

Question 26
Match the items of List – IwithList – II: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)List – Ia.Commentry-FourChambaultb. Midvale Steel Worksc.ChorltonTwist Companyd. CreditMobilierList – IIi. F.W. Taylorii. Claud Henry Saint Simoniii. Henry Fayoliv. Robert Owen
  • A.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • B.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

a. Commentry-Four Chambault – Henry Fayol

b. Midvale Steel Works – F. W. Taylor

c. Chorlton Twist Company – Robert Owen

d. Credit Mobilier – Claud Henry Saint Simon

 

Henri Fayol (1841 – 1925) was a French mining engineer, mining executive, author and director of mines who developed general theory of business administration that is often called Fayolism. Fayol's work was one of the first comprehensive statements of a general theory of management. He proposed that there were five primary functions of management and fourteen principles of management. In 1860, at the age of nineteen Fayol started working at the mining company named "Compagnie de Commentry-Fourchambault-Decazeville" in Commentry as the mining engineer. 

 

Frederick Winslow Taylor (1856 – 1915) was an American mechanical engineer who sought to improve industrial efficiency. His pioneering work in applying engineering principles to the work done on the factory floor was instrumental in the creation and development of the branch of engineering that is now known as industrial engineering. Taylor made his name, and was most proud of his work, in scientific management. Taylor finished his four-year apprenticeship and in 1878 became a machine-shop laborer at Midvale Steel Works. At Midvale, he was quickly promoted to time clerk, journeyman machinist, gang boss over the lathe hands, machine shop foreman, research director, and finally chief engineer of the works (while maintaining his position as machine shop foreman).

 

Robert Owen (1771 – 1858) was a Welsh textile manufacturer, philanthropic social reformer, and one of the founders of utopian socialism and the cooperative movement. Owen is best known for his efforts to improve the working conditions of his factory workers. In the early 1800s, Owen became wealthy as an investor and eventual manager of a large textile mill at New Lanark, Scotland. In 1792, mill-owner Peter Drinkwater made him manager of the Piccadilly Mill at Manchester; however, after two years of working for Drinkwater, Owen voluntarily gave up a contracted promise of partnership, left the company, and went into partnership with other entrepreneurs to establish and eventually manage the Chorlton Twist Mills in the Chorlton-on-Medlock area of Manchester.

 

Henri de Saint-Simon (1760 – 1825), was a French political and economic theorist and businessman whose thought played a substantial role in influencing politics, economics, sociology, and the philosophy of science. As a French reformer, he was best known for recognizing the need to replace debt relations by turning saving into equity (stock) investment. Among his followers, the Pereire brothers helped create the Credit Mobilier basically as a mutual fund. With less effect, St.-Simon sought to abolish inheritance so that people would possess only the fruits of their own labor.

Question 27
Match the following: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)List – I(a) Fayol(b) Taylor(c) Weber(d) Mooney and ReillyList – II(1) Economy and Society(2) General and Industrial Administration(3) Principles of Organization(4) Shop Management
  • A.a-(3) b-(4) c-(1) d-(2)
  • B.a-(2) b-(4) c-(1) d-(3)
  • C.a-(1) b-(3) c-(2) d-(4)
  • D.a-(4) b-(3) c-(2) d-(1)
Correct Answer: a-(2) b-(4) c-(1) d-(3)

(1) Economy and Society – It is a book by political economist and sociologist Max Weber, published in Germany in 1922.

(2) General and Industrial Administration - Henri Fayol's (a French Mining Engineer) work became more generally known with the 1949 publication of "General and industrial administration".

(3) Principles of Organization – James Mooney was a General Motors executive who teamed up with historian Alan Reilly to expose the true principles of an organization in their book, “Onward Industry”.

(4) Shop Management – F. W. Taylor's written works were designed for presentation to the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME). These include Notes on Belting (1894), A Piece-Rate System (1895), Shop Management (1903), Art of Cutting Metals (1906), and The Principles of Scientific Management (1911).

Question 28
Who among the following is not related to the planning function given by Taylor? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)
  • A.Route clerk
  • B.Time and cost clerk
  • C.Inspector
  • D.Disciplinarian
Correct Answer: Inspector

The question is related to one of the techniques of Scientific Management “Functional Foremanship” given by F. W. Taylor, popularly known as the father of Scientific Management. The Scientific Management School, stimulated by F.W. Taylor and carried on by others through the years, suggested a totally revolutionary way of thinking about the problems of work and organizations. Taylor has defined the basic problem of managing as the art of “knowing exactly what you want men to do and then see in that they do it in the best and cheapest way. Taylor a practicing manager, engineer, consultant, and written researcher was the most influential management pioneer. Taylor conducted various experiments at this work places to find out how human beings could be made more efficient by standardizing the work and better method of doing the work. 

 

His book "Principles of Scientific Management" had story of “Schmidt,” a stocky Pennsylvania German who was a pig-iron loader at Bethlehem Steel. Schmidt loaded about 12 tons of iron pigs each day. Using Taylor’s principles, “scientific managers” raised Schmidt’s output to 48 tons per day, and raised his daily wages from $1.15 to $1.85.

 

These experiments have provided the following techniques of scientific management:

(1) Separation of Planning and doing: Taylor emphasized the separation of planning aspect from actual doing the work. Taylor emphasized that planning should be left to supervisor and worker should have emphasis only on operational work.

 

(2) Functional Foremanship: Functional Foremanship : It is an extension of principle of division of labour, resulting in specialisation. According to Taylor, a single worker or supervisor cannot be expected to be an expert in all aspects. Thus, he advocated the appointment of eight foremen to guide workers, under planning and production departments.

 

Under the planning in charge, there are four personnel:

(i) Route clerk - responsible to specify the route of production.

(ii) Instruction card clerk - responsible to give instructions to the workers.

(iii) Time and cost clerk -responsible to prepare time and cost sheets.

(iv) Disciplinarian - responsible to maintain discipline among workers.

Under the production in charge, there are four personnel:

(i) Speed boss - responsible for timely completion of job.

(ii) Gang-boss - responsible for keeping machines and tools ready for work.

(iii) Repair boss - responsible to keep machines and tools in proper working condition.

(iv) Inspector - responsible to maintain quality of work. 

 

(3) Job Analysis: Job analysis is undertaken to find out the one best way of doing the thing. The best way of doing a job is one which requires the least movements. The best ways of doing the thing can be determined by taking up time-motion-fatigue studies. Time study involves the determination of time a movement takes to complete. The movement, which takes minimum time, is the best one. Motion study involves the study of movements in parts and is involved in doing a job and thereby eliminating the wasteful movements and performing only necessary movement. Fatigue study shows the amount and frequency of rest required in completing the work. Thus, job analysis, as given by Taylor suggests the fair amount of a day’s work requiring certain movements and rest periods to complete it.

 

(4) Standardization: As far as possible, standardization should be maintained in respect of instruments and tools, period of work, amount of work, working conditions cost of production etc. These things should be fixed in advance on the basis of job analysis and various elements of costs that to in performing a work.

 

(5) Scientific Selection and Training of Workers: Taylor has suggested that workers should be selected on scientific basis keeping into account their education, work experience, aptitude, physical strength etc. A worker should be given work for which he is physically on technically most suitable. Apart from selection, proper emphasis should be given on the training of workers, which makes them more efficient and effective.

 

(6) Financial Incentive / Pay Incentives: Financial incentives can motivate workers to put in their maximum efforts. To make the differential piece rate system work, Taylor has suggested that wages should be based on individual performance and not on the position, which he occupies. Further, the wage rate should be fixed on accurate knowledge and not on estimates.

 

(7) Economy: While applying Scientific Management, not only Scientific and technical aspects should be considered but adequate consideration should be given to economy and profit. 

 

(8) Mental Revolution: Scientific Management depends on the mutual co-operation between management and workers for this co-operation, there should be mental change in both parties from conflict to co-operation.

Question 29
Match the items of List-IwithList-II : (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)List-I(a) “He who can manage, can manage anything”.(b) “Due to these experiments, a factory does not remain a factory, it is converted into a laboratory”.(c) “Management succeeds or fails as human relations in business are intelligently or unintelligently handled”.(d) “A place for everything, and everything in its place”.List-II(i) Henry Fayol(ii) William B. Cornell(iii) F.W. Taylor(iv)LawranceA.Appley
  • A.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(iv)
  • B.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(ii) d-(i)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(ii) d-(i)

(a) “He who can manage, can manage anything”

It was declared by Lawrance A. Appley that “He who can manage, can manage anything” in the context that Management is ‘Universal’. Universality implies transferability of managerial skills across all levels, industries and countries.

 

(b) “Due to these experiments, a factory does not remain a factory, it is converted into a laboratory” 

The statement is related to Factory experiments conducted by F. W. Taylor (Father of Scientific Management), to increase the efficiency of workers.

 

(c) “Management succeeds or fails as human relations in business are intelligently or unintelligently handled” 

The statement was given by William B. Cornell on Organizational Development and Culture.

 

(d) “A place for everything, and everything in its place” 

This statement pertains to “Principle of Order” among the 14 principles of Management as given by Henri Fayol. Order conveys that there should be a place of everything and everything should be at its place. This applies not only to arrangement of materials and stores, but also to placement of personnel.

Question 30
Who is considered Father of Scientific Management? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.Peter Drucker
  • B.F.W. Taylor
  • C.Victor Vroom
  • D.Henry Fayol
Correct Answer: F.W. Taylor

Scientific management theory was developed in the early 20th century by Frederick W. Taylor. Scientific management theory is important because its approach to management is found in almost every industrial business operation across the world. Its influence is also felt in general business practices such planning, process design, quality control, cost accounting, and ergonomics.

 

Frederick W. Taylor was an American inventor and engineer. His two most important works were Shop Management (1903) and The Principles of Scientific Management (1911).

Question 31
Why has the bureaucratic form of organization been fundamentally questioned?(UGC NET Management Dec 2019)
  • A.Pressure of Globalization has rendered it unsuitable
  • B.Organizations are experiencing acute pressure to change and pursue innovation as a means of securing business growth
  • C.Organizations have grown so large that it is almost impossible to create an effective bureaucracy to manage them
  • D.Information Technology has made it redundant
Correct Answer: Organizations are experiencing acute pressure to change and pursue innovation as a means of securing business growth

Bureaucratic form of organization is characterized by strict policies for everything, which can slow down their operations and make communication difficult. For example, if the marketing department decides to try out a new strategy, it must first obtain approval from several other departments based on their order of importance within the company. This may lead to conflicts, poor employee relations, inefficiency and unhappy customers. The bureaucratic organizational structure may inhibit productivity, diminish innovation and decrease morale. The structure is inherently laden with rules and more policies and procedures can be added at any time, making workloads and roles more complicated.

 

But in today’s fast changing world, where organizations are operating under technological changes and high competition. To cope up with such dynamic environment, it is important for the organization to keep innovating and bringing new products to the customer. Bureaucratic form of organizations is not suitable for such dynamic environment as it restricts innovation.

Quiz Attempt #118943

Total Questions: 29
Question 1
The paper “Engineer as an Economist”, which influence F. W. Taylor to develop his Scientific Management Principles was authored by: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2012)
  • A.Charles A. Babbage
  • B.HenryGnatt
  • C.Henry R. Towne
  • D.Louis D. Brandies
Correct Answer: Henry R. Towne

Henry Robinson Towne was one of the first engineers to see management as a new social role for engineers and that the development of management techniques was important for the development of the engineering profession. He laid out his ideas about the management role for the engineer in his "The Engineer as Economist."

Question 2
Who is regarded as the father of Scientific Management? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)
  • A.Albert Bandura
  • B.Louis D. Brandies
  • C.Frederick Winslow Taylor
  • D.Elton Mayo
Correct Answer: Frederick Winslow Taylor

It was Louis D. Brandies who coined the term scientific management, however, Frederick Winslow Taylor is regarded as the father of Scientific Management.

Question 3
Match the following: (UGC NET HRM Jan 2017)List – I (Themes)a. POSDCORBb.EspiritDe Corpsc. Integration theoryd. The illumination experimentList – II (Propagators)i. Henry Fayolii. George A.Pennockiii. Mary ParkerFolletteiv. LutherGullick
  • A.a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
  • B.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-ii, d-iv
  • D.a-iv, b-ii, c-iii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii

a. POSDCORB – Luther Gullick

POSDCORB is an acronym widely used in the field of Management and Public Administration that reflects the classic view of Organizational theory. Luther Gullick has given a keyword ’POSDCORB’ where P stands for Planning, O for Organizing, S for Staffing, D for Directing, Co for Co-ordination, R for reporting & B for Budgeting.

 

b. Espirit De Corps – Henry Fayol

14 principles of Theory of General and Administrative Management were given by Henry Fayol. The 14 principles are Division of Work ,Authority and responsibility ,Discipline, Unity of Command ,Unity of Direction, Subordination of Individual Interest to General Interest, Remuneration, centralization vs Decentralization, Scalar Chain, Order, Equity, Stability of Tenure of personnel, Initiative and Espirit de Corps. "Espirit de Corps" means that Management should encourage harmony and general good feelings among employees.

 

c. Integration theory - Mary Parker Follette

M. P. Follett gave 4 ways of resolving conflict – domination, compromise, manipulation and integration. According to her, "Integration method" has its advantages. Bases of integration method are:

1. The first step to achieve integration is to bring the differences into the open instead of suppressing them. This is necessary to identify and understand real issues involved in a conflict.

2. Second step is to break demands of both parties in their constituent parts (individual issues).

3. Third step is anticipation of conflict. Anticipation does not mean avoidance of conflict but responding to it differently. To Follett, integration is like a game of chess. Anticipation of response by itself is not enough; there is need for preparation for response as well.

 

d. The illumination experiment  - George A. Pennock

The Hawthorne experiments were ground breaking studies in human relations that were conducted between 1924 and 1932 at Western Electric Company's Hawthorne Works in Chicago. Originally illumination studies were done to determine the relationship between lighting and productivity. George Pennock was Assistant Works Manager in Hawthorne plant had key role in illumination experiment. 

Question 4
Given below are two statements, onelabeledas Assertion, and the otherlabeledas Reason. (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2014)Assertion “A”:Classical organizations believed in the use of authority to achieve coordination.Reason “R”:Classical thinkers consider organization is an open system.
  • A.A is correct, but R is incorrect.
  • B.Both A and R are correct.
  • C.A is incorrect, but R is correct.
  • D.Both A and R are incorrect.
Correct Answer: A is correct, but R is incorrect.

The correct answer is (A) A is correct, but R is incorrect.

 

Assertion "A": Classical organizations believed in the use of authority to achieve coordination.

This statement is correct. Classical management thinkers, such as Frederick Taylor, Henri Fayol, and Max Weber, emphasized the importance of authority and hierarchical structures in achieving coordination and control within organizations. They believed that a clear chain of command, where authority flows from top to bottom, is essential for efficient and effective management.

 

Reason "R": Classical thinkers consider organization is an open system.

This statement is incorrect. Classical management thinkers did not consider organizations as open systems. In fact, the classical perspective treats organizations as closed systems, where the focus is on internal efficiency, stability, and control. They viewed organizations as machines that can be optimized through scientific management and bureaucratic principles. It was the later development of management theories, such as the systems theory and contingency theory, that introduced the concept of organizations as open systems, where they are influenced by and interact with their external environment.

Question 5
Which of the following is not a feature of Weber’s ‘Bureaucracy’? (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)
  • A.Hierarchy
  • B.Division of work
  • C.Official rules
  • D.Personal relationships
Correct Answer: Personal relationships

The correct answer is (D) Personal relationships.

 

Weber's 'Bureaucracy' is a model of organization based on a systematic approach to management, characterized by certain features:

 

(A) Hierarchy: Bureaucracies have a clear and well-defined hierarchical structure with levels of authority and responsibility.

 

(B) Division of work: Work is divided into specialized tasks to increase efficiency and effectiveness.

 

(C) Official rules: Bureaucracies have formalized rules and procedures that govern the behavior of employees and guide decision-making.

 

(D) Personal relationships: Personal relationships and favoritism are not part of the bureaucratic model. In a bureaucracy, decisions are based on objective criteria and rules rather than personal preferences.

 

Weber believed that bureaucracies are designed to be rational, efficient, and impersonal, with a focus on achieving organizational goals rather than catering to personal relationships or emotions.

Question 6
Consider the following. (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)Assertion “A”:Due to these experiments (Time, Motion and Fatigue Studies) a factory does not remain a factory, it is converted into a laboratory.Reasoning “R”:Management succeeds or fails as human relations in business are intelligently or unintelligently handled.
  • A.Both“A”and“R”are correct and“R”is the right explanation of“A”.
  • B.Both“A”and“R”are correct but“R”is not the right explanation of“A”.
  • C.“A”is correct but“R”is not correct.
  • D.“R”is correct but“A”is not correct.
Correct Answer: Both“A”and“R”are correct but“R”is not the right explanation of“A”.

The correct answer is (B) Both "A" and "R" are correct, but "R" is not the right explanation of "A."

 

Assertion "A" refers to the impact of time, motion, and fatigue studies on a factory. These studies are part of scientific management techniques aimed at improving work processes and efficiency. By conducting these experiments, the factory becomes more systematic and scientific in its approach to managing work.

 

Reasoning "R" is a general statement about management and human relations in business. It highlights the importance of handling human interactions intelligently for the success or failure of management practices. While this statement is true, it does not directly explain Assertion "A" about time, motion, and fatigue studies converting a factory into a laboratory.

Question 7
Span of management is determined by: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. Manager’s trainingII. Manager’s personal qualitiesIII. Subordinates trainingIV. Trade unionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.II, III, IV only
  • B.I, II, III only
  • C.I, III, IV only
  • D.I, II, IV only
Correct Answer: I, II, III only

The span of management refers to the number of subordinates that a manager can effectively supervise and manage. It is determined by various factors, including:

 

I. Manager's training: A well-trained manager with strong leadership and managerial skills can effectively handle a larger span of management.

 

II. Manager's personal qualities: Managerial qualities such as communication skills, decision-making abilities, and time management play a crucial role in determining the span of management.

 

III. Subordinates' training: If the subordinates are well-trained and capable of working independently, the manager can supervise a larger number of subordinates.

 

IV. Trade union: The presence of trade unions may not directly determine the span of management, as it is more related to the internal organizational structure and managerial capabilities.

Question 8
Promoting team spirit, harmony and unity within in the organization is the principle of : (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.order
  • B.scalar chain
  • C.spirit de corps
  • D.equity
Correct Answer: spirit de corps

The principle of esprit de corps, also known as team spirit or unity of morale, emphasizes the importance of promoting a sense of unity, harmony, and cooperation among the employees within the organization. When there is a strong team spirit, employees are more likely to work together effectively and support each other, leading to improved overall performance and productivity. Henri Fayol believed that a positive and cohesive work environment contributes to the success of an organization and helps in achieving common goals.

Question 9
Taylor advocated functional foremanship to introduce: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2021)
  • A.Standardization
  • B.Work Study
  • C.Specialization
  • D.Motion Study
Correct Answer: Specialization

Option (C) Specialization is the correct answer.

 

Taylor's functional foremanship is based on the idea of dividing the roles and responsibilities of a traditional supervisor into eight separate functional foremen, each responsible for a specific aspect of the workers' tasks. This division allows for specialization, as each functional foreman becomes an expert in their respective area of responsibility. The aim of functional foremanship was to achieve greater efficiency and productivity by ensuring that each task is performed by someone with the appropriate expertise and skill set.

Question 10
Taylor advocated ‘Functional Foremanship’ to introduce: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2019)
  • A.Differential piece-wage plan
  • B.Standardisation
  • C.Work study
  • D.Specialisation
Correct Answer: Specialisation

Option (D) Specialization is the correct answer.

 

Taylor's functional foremanship aimed to introduce specialization in management by dividing the roles of a traditional supervisor into eight specialized functional foremen. Four of these foremen were responsible for the planning aspects, and the other four were responsible for the execution aspects of the workers' tasks. This division allowed for greater efficiency and expertise in each area of responsibility, leading to improved productivity.

Question 11
Given below are two statements: One is labelled as Assertion A and other is labelled as Reason R: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2022)Assertion ‘A’:Henry Fayol was of the opinion that organizations should be based on group ethic rather than individuals.Reason ‘R’:Individual potential remains only potential until released through group association.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true but R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true but R is false.
  • D.A is false but R is true.
Correct Answer: A is false but R is true.

Mary Parker Follett was one of the first to recognize that organization could be viewed from the perspective of individual and group behaviour. Follett proposed more people-oriented ideas than scientific management followers and thought organizations should be based on group ethic.

 

She was a social philosopher whose ideas had clear implications for management practice. Her contribution towards the understanding of group is of immense value. She believed that groups were the mechanisms through which people could combine their differing talents for the greater good of the organization, which she defined as the community in which managers and subordinates could work in harmony. The Managers and workers should view themselves as partners and as a part of common group.

 

Therefore, Assertion is false while Reason is true.

Question 12
Consider the following. (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)Assertion 'A':Both Weber’s Bureaucracy and Taylor’s scientific management emphasise on rationality, predictability, impersonality, technical competence and authoritarianism.Reason 'R':Though Weber’s writings were less operational than Taylor’s, yet ‘ideal bureaucracy‘ describesmany contemporary organisations.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.A is right and R is wrong.
  • B.A is wrong and R is right.
  • C.Both A and R are right
  • D.Both A and R are wrong.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are right

The correct answer is (C) Both A and R are right.

 

Assertion 'A': Both Weber’s Bureaucracy and Taylor’s scientific management emphasize rationality, predictability, impersonality, technical competence, and authoritarianism.

Both Max Weber's Bureaucracy and Frederick Taylor's Scientific Management are classical management theories that aim to improve efficiency and productivity in organizations. They share certain common principles, such as the emphasis on rationality and predictability in organizational processes, the need for impersonal rules and procedures, the importance of technical competence in decision-making, and the authority of managers over workers.

 

Reason 'R': Though Weber’s writings were less operational than Taylor’s, yet ‘ideal bureaucracy‘ describes many contemporary organizations.

While Taylor's scientific management focused on the operational aspects of improving work processes and labor efficiency, Weber's Bureaucracy theory provided a more conceptual framework for understanding organizational structure and functioning. Weber's idea of the 'ideal bureaucracy' described certain characteristics of an efficient and rational organization, such as division of labor, hierarchical authority, clear rules and procedures, and merit-based selection of employees.

 

Many contemporary organizations, especially large and complex ones, exhibit features of the 'ideal bureaucracy' as described by Weber, even though Weber's writings were more theoretical and less operational compared to Taylor's scientific management. Thus, the reason is correct in stating that the 'ideal bureaucracy' concept is still applicable to many modern organizations.

Question 13
Who among the following is known for study of work arrangements to eliminate wasteful hand and body motions? (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)
  • A.Henry Gantt and C.I. Barnard
  • B.Frank and Lillian Gilbreth
  • C.Elton Mayo and H. Emerson
  • D.F.W. Taylor and Henry Gantt
Correct Answer: Frank and Lillian Gilbreth

The correct answer is (B) Frank and Lillian Gilbreth.

 

Frank and Lillian Gilbreth are known for their study of work arrangements to eliminate wasteful hand and body motions. They were pioneers in the field of time and motion study, which aimed to identify and eliminate unnecessary movements and improve efficiency in work processes. Frank and Lillian Gilbreth made significant contributions to scientific management and were proponents of the principles of motion study to improve worker productivity and reduce fatigue. Their work laid the foundation for modern ergonomic and efficiency studies in the workplace.

Question 14
Match the List - IwithList - II. (UGC NET HRM Jun 2015)List - Ia. Henry L. Ganttb. Max Weberc. Alex F.Osbormd. Henri FayolList - IIi. Theory of bureaucracyii. Father of modern/administrative management theoryiii. Graphic methods of describing plans and harmonious cooperationiv. Father of brain storming
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • C.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
  • D.a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

Let's explain each match in more detail:

a. Henry L. Gantt - iii. Graphic methods of describing plans and harmonious cooperation

Henry L. Gantt is known for his contribution to project management and planning. He developed the Gantt chart, which is a graphical representation of a project schedule. Gantt charts help to visualize the timeline of various tasks in a project, making it easier to plan and coordinate activities. The chart shows tasks on the vertical axis and time on the horizontal axis. It also uses bars to represent the duration of each task, making it easy to see the progress and dependencies of different activities. This graphical method of planning and coordination became widely used in project management.

 

b. Max Weber - i. Theory of bureaucracy

Max Weber is known for his theory of bureaucracy, which emphasizes the rational and efficient organization of large institutions and organizations. According to Weber, a bureaucracy is a type of organizational structure characterized by hierarchy, division of labor, formal rules and procedures, impersonal relationships, and specialized roles. He believed that bureaucracy could achieve greater efficiency and predictability in the administration of large organizations. Weber's work on bureaucracy has had a significant influence on organizational theory and management practices.

 

c. Alex F. Osborn - iv. Father of brainstorming
