Draws together concepts, principles, techniques, and knowledge from other fields of managerial approach: The Operational approach integrates various management theories and practices from different fields to create a comprehensive and practical approach to managing organizations.

 

D. Contingency approach - II. Managerial practice depends on circumstances: The Contingency approach suggests that there is no one-size-fits-all method to management; instead, the best approach depends on the specific circumstances and environment in which decisions are made.

 

This confirms that the correct answer is (A) A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II.

Question 5
Arrange the following Historical Events in operations management in the order of sequence starting from oldest to newest. (UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. Quality RevolutionB. Scientific ManagementC. Industrial RevolutionD. Operations ResearchE. Human RelationsChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.C, B, E, D, A
  • B.B, C, D, E, A
  • C.A, B, D, C. E
  • D.E, C, B, A, D
Correct Answer: C, B, E, D, A

The correct sequence of historical events in operations management from oldest to newest is:

C. Industrial Revolution: Marked the beginning of modern industry with the introduction of mechanized production (late 18th century).

B. Scientific Management: Introduced by Frederick Taylor in the early 20th century, focusing on improving efficiency through time and motion studies.

E. Human Relations: Emerged in the 1930s, emphasizing the importance of people in the workplace and their impact on productivity.

D. Operations Research: Developed during World War II and became prominent in the mid-20th century, applying mathematical and analytical methods to solve complex operational problems.

A. Quality Revolution: Gained momentum in the late 20th century, focusing on continuous improvement and total quality management (TQM).

 

So, the correct answer is (A) C, B, E, D, A.

Question 6
Who wrote the book, ‘The Concept of the Corporation’? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2023)
  • A.Mary Parker Follet
  • B.C. I. Barnard
  • C.Luther Gullick
  • D.Peter F Drucker
Correct Answer: Peter F Drucker

Peter F. Drucker wrote the book titled "The Concept of the Corporation." It was published in 1946 and is considered one of his seminal works on management and organizational theory.

Question 7
Match List I with List II (UGC NET HRM Jun 2023)List IA. Frank GilbertB. Hugo MunsterbergC. RoethlisbergerD. Chester BarnardList III. Industrial PsychologyII. Social relationships of work groupsIII. Time and motion studiesIV. Functions of the executiveChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A - IV, B - III, C- II, D - I
  • B.A - I, B – II, C - III, D - IV
  • C.A – III, B - I, C - II, D - IV
  • D.A - III, B – II, C - I, D - IV
Correct Answer: A – III, B - I, C - II, D - IV

The correct match is as follows.

List I – List II

A. Frank Gilbert - Time and motion studies

B. Hugo Munsterberg - Industrial Psychology

C. Roethlisberger - Social relationships of work groups

D. Chester Barnard - Functions of the executive

Question 8
Which of the following is/are correct relating to the system approach to management? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2023)(A) A system is an interrelated set of elements punching as a whole(B) Each system has a boundary that separates it from its environment(C) Each system interacts with its environment(D) Feedback is not the key to control the systemChoose the coned answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and B Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.A, B and C Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, B and C Only

Here is explanation.

 

(A) A system is an interrelated set of elements functioning as a whole: This statement accurately describes a fundamental concept of the system approach to management, emphasizing that a system comprises interconnected components that work together to achieve a common purpose.

(B) Each system has a boundary that separates it from its environment: This statement is also consistent with the system approach, as systems are defined by boundaries that distinguish them from their external environment. These boundaries help in understanding the system's scope and interactions with its surroundings.

(C) Each system interacts with its environment: This statement is true and aligns with the system approach, emphasizing the dynamic relationship between a system and its environment. Systems continually exchange inputs, outputs, and feedback with their surroundings, influencing and being influenced by external factors.

(D) Feedback is not the key to control the system: This statement is incorrect. Feedback is indeed a crucial aspect of controlling systems in the context of the system approach to management. Feedback mechanisms allow systems to monitor their performance, detect deviations from desired outcomes, and make necessary adjustments to maintain stability and achieve goals. Therefore, option (D) is not correct.

 

So, the correct answer is (C) A, B and C Only.

Question 9
Arrange the following management concepts in terms of period of evolution from earliest to latest: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2023)(A) Informal organisation(B) Time and motion study(C) Six sigma(D) Need hierarchy model(E) Management by objectivesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(B)>(D)>(A)>(E)>(C)
  • B.(B)>(D)>(A)>(C)>(E)
  • C.(B)>(A)>(D)>(E)>(C)
  • D.(A)>(B)>(D)>(C)>(E)
Correct Answer: (B)>(A)>(D)>(E)>(C)

The management concepts are arranged based on their period of evolution from earliest to latest as follows:

 

1. Time and motion study - Originating in the early 20th century, time-and-motion studies were first introduced in offices and factories in the United States.

 

2. Informal organization - The concept of informal organization was observed in experiments conducted in the early 1930s, where researchers noted the presence of a social organization alongside the technical one governing worker behavior.

 

3. Need hierarchy model - Abraham Maslow introduced the need hierarchy model in 1943 in his paper "Theory of Motivation," outlining a hierarchy of needs starting from basic ones to higher levels.

 

4. Management by objectives - Coined by Peter F. Drucker in 1954 in his book "The Practice of Management," the term "management by objectives (MBO)" emerged as a significant management approach.

 

5. Six Sigma - Six Sigma was developed by Bill Smith and Mikel Harry at Motorola in 1986. It gained widespread adoption when Jack Welch made it the central business strategy of General Electric in 1995.

 

Therefore, the correct arrangement is option (C).

Question 10
Match List - I with List - II. (UGC NET HRM Dec 2023)List - I (Name)(A) Max Weber(B) Chester I. Barnard(C) Vilfredo Pareto(D) Joan WoodwardList - II (Concept)(I) Social systems approach(II) Hierarchy(III) Unit production(IV) Informal structureChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(A)-(II), (B)-(I), (C)-(IV), (D)-(III)
  • B.(A)-(II), (B)-(IV), (C)-(I), (D)-(III)
  • C.(A)-(III), (B)-(I), (C)-(IV), (D)-(II)
  • D.(A)-(II), (B)-(I), (C)-(III), (D)-(IV)
Correct Answer: (A)-(II), (B)-(IV), (C)-(I), (D)-(III)

To match List I (Name) with List II (Concept), we need to identify the concepts associated with each individual:

 

(A) Max Weber - Known for his work on bureaucracy and the idea of hierarchical structures in organizations.

Associated with: Hierarchy (II)

 

(B) Chester I. Barnard - Known for his contributions to management theory and the social systems approach.

Associated with: Social systems approach (I)

 

(C) Vilfredo Pareto -Known for his contributions to economics and sociology, particularly the Pareto principle and his work on social and economic systems.

Associated with: Informal structure (IV)

 

(D) Joan Woodward - Known for her research on industrial organization and the classification of production systems, such as unit production, mass production, and process production.

Associated with: Unit production (III)

Question 11
Which approach of management emphasizes that "the task of managers is to identify which technique will, in a particular situation, under particular circumstances, and at a particular time, best contribute to the attainment of management goals?"(UGC NET HRM Jun 2024)
  • A.Behavioral approach
  • B.System approach
  • C.Quantitative approach
  • D.Contingency approach
Correct Answer: Contingency approach

The Contingency Approach to management emphasizes that there is no one-size-fits-all method for managing organizations. Instead, it suggests that managers should assess the specific circumstances of a situation and select the appropriate techniques or strategies that will effectively contribute to achieving management goals based on those unique conditions. This approach recognizes the variability of situations and the need for flexible management practices.

Question 12
Which of the following is NOT correct relating to the classical approach of management? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2024)
  • A.An organisation is a socio technical system
  • B.Functions, principles and skills of management are considered universal
  • C.Formal education and training are emphasised for developing managerial skills
  • D.Emphasis is placed on economic efficiency
Correct Answer: An organisation is a socio technical system

The correct answer is (A) An organisation is a socio-technical system.

 

The classical approach to management primarily focuses on efficiency, formal structure, and the rational organization of tasks. Key characteristics of this approach include:

(B) Functions, principles, and skills of management are considered universal: This is a correct feature of the classical approach, as it posits that management principles (such as planning, organizing, leading, and controlling) can be universally applied to any organization.

(C) Formal education and training are emphasized for developing managerial skills: The classical approach emphasizes the importance of systematic training and education for managers to ensure they are capable of applying the universal principles of management effectively.

(D) Emphasis is placed on economic efficiency: The classical approach is particularly concerned with increasing productivity and efficiency, which is a major focus of its principles, such as time and motion studies.

 

However, (A) An organisation is a socio-technical system is not part of the classical approach. This concept comes from the socio-technical systems theory, which emerged later as a way to balance both the social and technical aspects of an organization. The classical approach typically does not consider the human or social elements of the organization in as much detail as the socio-technical systems theory does.

Question 13
Match List I and List II:(UGC NET HRM Jun 2020)List IA. group influences in the workplaceB. Administrative theory – Rules of ManagementC. Father of Modern Management TheoryD. systems theoryList III. Max WeberII. Chester BarnardIII. Mary Parker FollettIV. Henri FayolChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • B.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
  • C.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • D.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
Correct Answer: A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II

The correct matching of List I with List II is as follows:

 

A. group influences in the workplace - Mary Parker Follett

B. Administrative theory – Rules of Management - Max Weber

C. Father of Modern Management Theory - Henri Fayol

D. Systems theory - Chester Barnard

 

So, the correct answer is (C) A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II.

Question 14
Which approach suggests that there is no best way to handle any of the management problems and there is no best organizational structure to suit all situations? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2020)
  • A.Operational Approach
  • B.Contingency Approach
  • C.Case/ empirical Approach
  • D.System Approach
Correct Answer: Contingency Approach

The contingency approach suggests that there is no best way to handle all of the management problems and there is no organizational structure to suit all the situations. A structure will be suitable only if it is tailor made for an enterprise. This approach suggests that needs, requirements, situations of a particular concern should be considered while designing an organizational structure. The influence of both internal and external factors should be considered in this context.  

 

The fundamental basis of contingency theory is that there is no best way to manage a corporation or to deal with employees. Such activities cannot be planned, because so many things change so quickly in the business world. Rather than being proactive, managers and business leaders must be reactive to the various changes and contingencies they face on a day-to-day basis. The contingency theory of leadership holds that the success of a business leader or manager is contingent on numerous internal and external factors facing him. Internal factors include the character and quality of his subordinates, the level of support received from superiors within the organization and the tasks assigned to him. External factors include economic concerns, the level of competition in the marketplace and relationships with channel partners and business partners, among others.

Question 15
Which approach suggests that there is no best way to handle any of the management problems and there is no best organizational structure to suit all situations? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2021)
  • A.Quantitative Approach
  • B.Contingency Approach
  • C.System Approach
  • D.Behavioural Approach
Correct Answer: Contingency Approach

Option B is correct.

 

The contingency approach stresses that there is no single way to manage effectively under all circumstances. The methods of behaviours which work effectively in one situation may fail in another. The organisational structure and the processes of management are governed by the external environment and several aspects of the internal environment. The manager’s task therefore, is to identify which method will, in a particular situation, under particular circumstances and at a particular time, best contribute to the attainment of organization’s goals.

Question 16
Consider the following management theories:(a) Systems theory(b) Quantitative theory(c) Behavioural Science theory(d) Contingency theoryWhich of the above are modern management theories? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2019)
  • A.(a) and (b) only
  • B.(a) and (c)
  • C.(a), (b) and (d) only
  • D.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (d) only

The correct answer is (C) (a), (b), and (d) only. These theories are considered modern management theories:

(a) Systems theory

(b) Quantitative theory

(d) Contingency theory

 

These theories have emerged more recently and have shaped modern management practices and perspectives.

Question 17
Match the following. (UGC NET HRM Jun 2021)List Ia. Elton Mayob. F. W. Taylorc. Henri Fayold. Chester BarnardList IIi. Father of Modern Management Theoryii. Hawthorne effectiii. Comprehensive social system approachiv. Principles of scientific management
  • A.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
  • B.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • D.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Here's an explanation for each of the matches:

 

a. Elton Mayo (ii) - Hawthorne Effect:

Elton Mayo is best known for his work in the Hawthorne Studies, which were conducted at the Western Electric Hawthorne Works in Chicago. The Hawthorne effect refers to the phenomenon where individuals alter their behavior when they are aware of being observed. In the Hawthorne Studies, Mayo and his colleagues found that changes in the work environment, such as improved lighting or rest breaks, had a positive impact on workers' productivity. They realized that the presence of a research team and the attention given to workers during the experiments positively influenced their productivity.

 

b. F.W. Taylor (iv) - Principles of Scientific Management:

F.W. Taylor is often regarded as the father of scientific management. He developed a set of principles known as the "Principles of Scientific Management." Taylor's approach emphasized the application of scientific methods to management, with a focus on optimizing work processes and increasing productivity. His principles included things like time and motion studies, breaking down tasks into smaller, more manageable elements, and providing appropriate incentives to workers to encourage higher efficiency.

 

c. Henri Fayol (i) - Father of Modern Management Theory:

Henri Fayol is known as one of the pioneers of modern management theory. He is often referred to as the "father of modern management." Fayol's work emphasized the importance of management functions and principles. He identified five key functions of management: planning, organizing, commanding, coordinating, and controlling. These functions formed the foundation of modern management theory and are still widely taught and practiced in management today.

 

d. Chester Barnard (iii) - Comprehensive Social System Approach:

Chester Barnard introduced the concept of a comprehensive social system approach to management. He emphasized that organizations are complex social systems and not just mechanical structures. Barnard believed that an organization is a cooperative system in which individuals work together to achieve common goals. His approach highlighted the significance of communication and cooperation within organizations, and it encouraged management and organization theorists to view organizations as complex and dynamic social systems.

Question 18
Consider the following. (UGC NET Commerce Jan 2017)Assertion “A”:The organization is a closed system that operates within and interacts with the external environment.Reasoning “R”:The system approach to management includes the outputs from the external environment on the basis of interactions between management and employees.
  • A.“A”and“R”are correct and“R”is the correct reasoning of“A”.
  • B.“A”and“R”are correct, but“R”is not the correct explanation of“A”.
  • C.“A”is incorrect while“R”is a correct statement.
  • D.Both“A”and“R”are incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both“A”and“R”are incorrect.

The assertion "A" and the reasoning "R" provided in the question are both incorrect. Here's an explanation:

 

Assertion "A" states that the organization is a closed system that operates within and interacts with the external environment. This assertion is not accurate. In fact, organizations are considered open systems, not closed systems. Open systems interact with their external environments, which means they exchange information, resources, and energy with the outside world. Closed systems, on the other hand, do not interact with their external environment. Therefore, the organization is not a closed system but an open system.

 

Reasoning "R" suggests that the system approach to management includes the outputs from the external environment on the basis of interactions between management and employees. This reasoning is also not accurate. The system approach to management does consider interactions between the organization and its external environment, but it's not solely focused on the interactions between management and employees. It looks at the organization as a whole, including its internal and external elements, and how they interact to achieve organizational goals.

 

Therefore, both "A" and "R" are incorrect, and option (D) is the correct choice.

Question 19
The author of the book “The World is Flat: A Brief History of the Twenty First Century” is
  • A.Thomas L. Friedman
  • B.RaghuramRajan
  • C.Michael Armstrong
  • D.VineetNayyar
Correct Answer: Thomas L. Friedman

The World Is Flat: A Brief History of the Twenty-first Century is an international best-selling book by Thomas L. Friedman that analyses globalization, primarily in the early 21st century. The title is a metaphor for viewing the world as a level playing field in terms of commerce, wherein all competitors have an equal opportunity.

Question 20
It is believed that employees’ attitude influences their perception of work, but the employees' experience at work may also modify or shape their attitudes. This is an example of:[UGC NET Management June 2021]
  • A.Contingency Approach
  • B.Democratic Approach
  • C.Interactional Approach
  • D.Socio‐technical system Approach
Correct Answer: Interactional Approach

The correct answer is indeed option (C) - Interactional Approach.

 

The interactional approach in organizational behavior recognizes the dynamic and reciprocal relationship between an employee's attitudes and their experiences at work. This approach acknowledges that employees' attitudes can influence their perceptions of work, but their actual experiences and interactions at work can also shape and modify their attitudes. It emphasizes the interplay between individual factors, such as personality and values, and situational factors, such as job design and organizational culture.

Question 21
Which one of the following approaches stresses that there are no universal rules for managers to follow in order to perform the job?[UGC NET Management June 2021]
  • A.Contingency
  • B.System
  • C.Mathematical
  • D.Empirical
Correct Answer: Contingency

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Contingency refers to the immediate contingent circumstances.

 

The contingency approach to management assumes that there is no universal answer to many questions because organizations, people, and situations vary and change over time. The approach is based on the idea that there is no single best way to manage.

 

Effective organizations must tailor their planning, organizing, leading, and controlling to their particular circumstances.

Question 22
Find the correct sequence of management theories in their origin: (UGC NET Management Jun 2020)a.Bertalanffy’ssystem theoryb. Elton Mayo – Human Relation Management theoryc. Max Weber- Bureaucracy management theoryd. F.W Taylor- scientific management theorye. Henri Fayol – Administrative management theoryChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-b-c-d-e
  • B.e-d-a-b-c
  • C.c-b-d-a-e
  • D.d-e-c-b-a
Correct Answer: d-e-c-b-a

The correct sequence of management theories is given below:

F.W Taylor- scientific management theory 1911

Henri Fayol – Administrative management theory 1916

Max Weber- Bureaucracy management theory 1920s

Elton Mayo – Human Relation Management theory 1924

Bertalanffy’s - System theory 1968

Question 23
The approaches to management thinking which were developed during the first half of the 20thcentury is: (UGC NET Management Jun 2020)a. Scientific management, general administrative, quantitative and contingency approachb. Scientific management, general administrative, quantitative and organisational behaviourc. General administrative, globalisation, organisational behaviour and quantitiesd. System approach, scientific management, general administrative and organisational behaviourChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a and b
  • B.b and c
  • C.b only
  • D.d only
Correct Answer: b only

The correct answer is indeed (C) - "b only."

 

The approaches to management thinking developed during the first half of the 20th century include scientific management, general administrative, quantitative, and organizational behavior. These approaches have played significant roles in shaping management theory and practice during that period.

Question 24
Match the terms with the statement given below:(UGC NET Management Dec 2019)List I(a) Human behaviour results from a continuous and multidirectional interaction between the person and the situation(b) People are central to the organization and they must be developed to their potential(c) Manager’s efficiency depends on optimum utilization of resources(d) The belief that there is no one best option available for an organizationList II(i) Interactionalism(ii) Productivity Approach(iii) Contingency Approach(iv) HR ApproachSelect the correct option:
  • A.(a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iv)
  • D.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)

The correct answer is (A) - "(a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)."

 

Here is an explanation for each matching term:

 

(a) Human behaviour results from a continuous and multidirectional interaction between the person and the situation (i) Interactionalism: Interactionalism is an approach that emphasizes that human behavior results from a continuous and multidirectional interaction between the individual's characteristics and the situation. It recognizes that both personal attributes and environmental factors influence behavior. This approach highlights the dynamic and reciprocal relationship between people and their surroundings.

 

(b) People are central to the organization and they must be developed to their potential (iv) HR Approach: The Human Resource (HR) approach emphasizes that people are a central resource in any organization. It underscores the importance of developing individuals to their full potential, recognizing that when employees are developed and motivated, they contribute to the success of the organization. This approach focuses on the value of human capital.

 

(c) Manager’s efficiency depends on optimum utilization of resources (ii) Productivity Approach: The Productivity Approach emphasizes the importance of optimizing resource utilization in an organization. It measures efficiency by assessing the ratio of output to input. Higher productivity indicates greater efficiency in utilizing resources. Managers are expected to make the most efficient use of available resources to enhance organizational performance.

 

(d) The belief that there is no one best option available for an organization (iii) Contingency Approach: The Contingency Approach asserts that there is no one-size-fits-all solution for organizations. It acknowledges that the best course of action or management approach depends on the specific circumstances or contingencies faced by the organization. The approach considers that various situational factors influence the effectiveness of different strategies, and solutions must be tailored to match the unique situation of each organization.

Question 25
OB has been influenced by which of the following trends: (UGC NET HRM Aug 2016)
  • A.The systems approach
  • B.The socio-technical system approach
  • C.The contingency approach
  • D.The interactional approach
Correct Answer: The contingency approach

The correct answer is (C) - "The contingency approach."

 

Organizational Behavior (OB) has indeed been influenced by various trends, but the options provided in your question appear to be related to different management approaches rather than trends. The contingency approach is one of the significant management approaches that have influenced OB. It recognizes that organizational systems are interrelated with their environment, and the organization's effectiveness depends on how well it aligns its internal structure with the demands of its external environment.

 

The other approaches mentioned in the explanation, such as the systems approach and socio-technical system approach, are indeed important in management theory, but they are not trends. OB has evolved by integrating various management approaches and considering contemporary trends, as mentioned in a previous response.

Question 26
Match the following: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)List-Ia. The Practice of Managementb. Philosophy of Managementc. Principles of Scientific Managementd. General and Industrial AdministrationList-II1. Henry Fayol2. F.W. Taylor3. Oliver Sheldon4. Peter F. Drucker
  • A.a-1, b-2, c-3, d-4
  • B.a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1
  • C.a-4, b-3, c-1, d-2
  • D.a-3, b-4, c-2, d-1
Correct Answer: a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1

The questions involves the name of the famous books and their respective authors.

a. The Practice of Management - Peter F. Drucker

Peter Drucker (1909–2005) was the 20th century’s leading thinker on business and management. Drucker’s The Practice of Management (1954) played a pivotal role in the recognition of management as a professional discipline.

 

b. Philosophy of Management – Oliver Sheldon

In 1923, Oliver Sheldon developed a philosophy of management. Two Books written by him are, "The Philosophy of Management" and "The art of management: from a British point of view".

 

c. Principles of Scientific Management - F. W. Taylor

F. W. Taylor a practicing manager, engineer, consultant, and written researcher was the most influential management pioneer. Taylor conducted various experiments at this work places to find out how human beings could be made more efficient by standardizing the work and better method of doing the work. He is generally accepted as the “Father of Scientific Management”. His book "Principles of Scientific Management" had story of “Schmidt,” a stocky Pennsylvania German who was a pig-iron loader at Bethlehem Steel. Schmidt loaded about 12 tons of iron pigs each day. Using Taylor’s principles, “scientific managers” raised Schmidt’s output to 48 tons per day, and raised his daily wages from $1.15 to $1.85.

 

d. General and Industrial Administration – Henry Fayol

Fayol's work became more generally known with the 1949 publication of "General and Industrial Administration". In this work, Fayol presented his theory of management, known as Fayolism. Before that, Fayol had written several articles on mining engineering, starting in the 1870s, and some preliminary papers on administration.

Question 27
Match the following: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2015)(Book)(a) Functions of the Executive(b) On the Economy of Machinery and Manufactures(c) The Effective Executive(d) General and Industrial Administration(Author)(i) Charles Babbage(ii) Henri Fayol(iii) Chester Barnard(iv) Peter Drucker
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(iv), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(ii)

The correct matches are given below:

(a) Functions of the Executive – Chester Bernard

(b) On the Economy of Machinery and Manufactures – Charles Babbage

(c) The Effective Executive – Peter Drucker

(d) General and Industrial Administration – Henri Fayol

Question 28
Match the following: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2009)Proponents(a) F. W. Taylor(b) Elton Mayo(c) WilliamOuchi(d)RensisLikertManagement thought(i) Systems theory(ii) ‘Z’ theory(iii) Scientific Management(iv) Human Relations
  • A.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(iii), d-(i)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(iv), d-(i)
  • C.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)

The correct answer is (D) - "a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(i)."

 

Here's an explanation for each matching term:

 

(a) F. W. Taylor - Scientific Management:

F. W. Taylor is associated with the Scientific Management theory. This theory focuses on optimizing and standardizing work processes to improve efficiency and productivity. It emphasizes systematic analysis and scientific methods to identify the best way to perform tasks.

 

(b) Elton Mayo - Human Relations:

Elton Mayo is linked to the Human Relations theory. The Hawthorne studies conducted under his supervision highlighted the importance of social and psychological factors in the workplace. Human Relations theory emphasizes the significance of employee morale, satisfaction, and interpersonal relationships in organizational performance.

 

(c) William Ouchi - 'Z' Theory:

William Ouchi is known for the 'Z' Theory, which is a management approach that combines Japanese and American management practices. Theory Z emphasizes long-term employment, employee involvement, and a strong focus on the well-being of employees. It aims to create a corporate culture that values employee loyalty and commitment.

 

(d) Rensis Likert - Systems Theory:

Rensis Likert is associated with Systems Theory in management. His System 4 theory focuses on participative and group-oriented management. It emphasizes building trust, open communication, and collaboration within the organization. This theory aims to create a more effective and productive work environment.

Question 29
Which of the following is not a feature of systems approach? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2013)
  • A.A system is a combination of parts
  • B.Parts and sub-parts are related to one another
  • C.It is not necessary for a system to have a boundary
  • D.System transforms inputs into outputs
Correct Answer: It is not necessary for a system to have a boundary

Systems Theory was first introduced by Van Bertalanffy (1950) and was introduced into the organisational setting by Katz and Khan (1966).  Systems theory is an approach to organisations which likens the enterprise to an organism with interdependent parts, each with its own specific function and interrelated responsibilities.  The system may be the whole organisation, a division, department or team.

 

The key points are: 

1. The organisation is an open system, which interacts with the environment and is continually adapting and improving. 

2. The organisation influences and is influenced by the environment in which it operates 

3. If an organisation is to be effective it must pay attention to the external environment, and take steps to adjust itself to accommodate the changes in order to remain relevant 

4. All part of the organisation are interconnected and interdependent; If one part of the system is affected, all parts are. 

Question 30
Match the following: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2009)Contributor(a) Chester I. Barnard(b) Max Weber(c) F.W. Taylor(d) Katz and KahnOrganisation Theory(i) Functional Foremanship(ii) Acceptance Theory of Authority(iii) Open System Theory(iv) Bureaucracy
  • A.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(ii)
  • C.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(iv), d-(i)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)

The correct answer is (D) - "a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)."

 

Here's an explanation for each matching term:

 

(a) Chester I. Barnard - Acceptance Theory of Authority:

Chester Barnard is associated with the Acceptance Theory of Authority. This theory emphasizes that a manager's authority is effective when it is accepted by workers. The acceptance theory of authority posits that employees need to believe that a manager has the legitimate right to give orders, and there is a legitimate expectation that these orders will be carried out. It highlights the importance of employees accepting the authority of their managers.

 

(b) Max Weber - Bureaucracy:

Max Weber is well-known for his theory of bureaucracy. Bureaucracy, as outlined by Weber, involves a hierarchical organization structure with clear lines of authority, formal rules and regulations, division of labor, and impersonal relationships. It is a structured and rational approach to organizing and managing activities within an organization.

 

(c) F.W. Taylor - Functional Foremanship:

F.W. Taylor introduced the concept of Functional Foremanship as part of his scientific management approach. Functional Foremanship involves the separation of planning and execution tasks. Each worker is supervised by different specialists for various aspects of their job. This approach aims to improve efficiency and expertise in managing workers.

 

(d) Katz and Kahn - Open System Theory:

Katz and Kahn are associated with Open System Theory. This theory views organizations as open systems that interact with their environment. It emphasizes that organizations receive inputs from their external environment, process these inputs internally, and produce outputs that may influence the external environment. Open System Theory recognizes the dynamic relationship between organizations and their surroundings.

 

So, the correct match is (D), with each contributor aligned with their respective organization theory.

Question 31
Match the following: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2015)List I-Statement(a) Organisation has interconnected and interrelated elements.(b) Organisations work through motivation, leadership, communication and participative management.(c) Management is essentially decision making.(d) Appropriate managerial action depends on external environment, internal states and needs.List II-Approach(i) Decision theory approach(ii) Systems approach(iii) Human Behaviour approach(iv) Contingency approach
  • A.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(iv), d-(i)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • C.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(iv)

The correct answer is (B) - "a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)."

 

Here's an explanation for each matching term:

 

(a) Organisation has interconnected and interrelated elements - Systems approach:

The systems approach views organizations as interconnected and interrelated elements that form a unified whole. It emphasizes that an organization consists of interdependent parts or subsystems that work together as a unified system. This approach is concerned with understanding how these parts interact and influence each other.

 

(b) Organisations work through motivation, leadership, communication, and participative management - Human Behavior approach:

The Human Behavior approach (also known as the Human Relations approach) emphasizes that organizations function through understanding and managing human behavior. It recognizes the importance of factors like motivation, leadership, communication, and participative management in improving organizational performance. This approach focuses on the social and psychological aspects of the workplace.

 

(c) Management is essentially decision making - Decision theory approach:

The Decision Theory approach in management emphasizes that management is fundamentally about decision-making. It involves using logical concepts and models to help managers make effective decisions. Decision theory considers that organizational members are decision-makers and problem solvers, and the quality of decisions directly impacts organizational effectiveness.

 

(d) Appropriate managerial action depends on external environment, internal states, and needs - Contingency approach:

The Contingency approach in management acknowledges that the most appropriate managerial actions depend on various factors, including the external environment, internal states of the organization, and specific needs of the situation. This approach recognizes that there is no universal or one-size-fits-all management solution, and the best course of action varies based on the specific circumstances and contingencies faced by the organization.

 

So, the correct match is (B), with each statement aligned with its respective management approach.

Question 32
Who had advocated the systems approach model? (UGC NET HRM Sep 2013)
  • A.John T. Dunlop
  • B.Herbert A. Spencer
  • C.Charles A. Spaulding
  • D.Talcott Parsons
Correct Answer: John T. Dunlop

The systems approach is given by Prof. John T. Dunlop of the Harvard University (1958) and is also referred as Dunlop’s Approach. Dunlop analyses industrial relations system as a subsystem of the society. He suggested that industrial relations system could be divided into four interrelated elements comprising certain actors, certain contexts, an ideology binding the industrial relations system together and a body of rules created to govern the actors at the workplace. Elements of System Model of Industrial Relation are 1) The Actors in the system 2) The Contexts of systems 3) The Ideology of an Industrial Relations System 4) The Network or Web of Rules.

Question 33
Which of the following statements about open systems as given by Daniel Katz and Robert Khan are true? (UGC NET HRM Jan 2017)a. The exportation ofenergicinputs into the environment.b. Transformation of available energy as throughput, so that work is done.c. The importation of the output from the environment.d. A cycle of events in which the product exported to the environment provides the energy for repetition of the cycle.
  • A.a, b
  • B.b, c
  • C.b, d
  • D.a, d
Correct Answer: b, d

The correct answer is (C) - "b, d."

 

Here's an explanation for each of the true statements:

 

b. Transformation of available energy as throughput, so that work is done:

This statement is true. In open systems, such as organizations, there is a process of transforming the available energy and resources (input) into a productive and useful form (throughput). Through this transformation, work is done within the system to achieve its goals and objectives. This is a fundamental concept of open systems theory.

 

d. A cycle of events in which the product exported to the environment provides the energy for repetition of the cycle:

This statement is also true. Open systems operate in a cyclical manner, where the product or output generated by the system is exported to the environment. This exported product can, in turn, serve as a source of energy or resources for the system to repeat the cycle. It's a key characteristic of open systems to sustain themselves by utilizing the outcomes of their activities to continue their operations.

 

These concepts are important in understanding how open systems function, and they are part of the systems theory framework developed by Daniel Katz and Robert Kahn.

Question 34
Match List IwithList IIList I (Authors)(a) Douglas C McGregor(b) Elton Mayo(c) Herbert A. Simon(d) Chester BarnardList II (Books)(i) Functions of the Executive(ii) The New Science of Management Decision(iii) The Human Side of Enterprise(iv) Human Problems of an Industrial CivilizationChoose your answer from the following options:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(iii), (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
  • C.(a)-(i), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)

The correct match of books with authors is given below:

(a) Douglas C McGregor - The Human Side of Enterprise

(b) Elton Mayo - Human Problems of an Industrial Civilization

(c) Herbert A. Simon - The New Science of Management Decision

(d) Chester Barnard - Functions of the Executive

Question 35
Match List IwithList IIList I – Management concepts and theoriesA. System theoryB. Contingency theoryC. Organization designD. Total Quality ManagementList II – DescriptionI. Customer oriented approach emphasizing human resources and quantitative methods to continuously improveII. Concerned with formal patterns of arrangements and relationship developed by ManagementIII. Based on open-systems theory and recognizes that there are many, internal and external factors that influence organizational behaviourIV. All parts of an organization are interrelated and dependent on one anotherChoose the correct answer from the options given below: [UGC NET Management June 2022]
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-II, B-III, C-I, D-IV
  • C.A-I, B-II, C-IV, D-III
  • D.A-III, B-I, C-II, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I

The correct answer is (A) - "A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I."

 

Here's an explanation for each matching term:

 

A. System theory matches with "All parts of an organization are interrelated and dependent on one another." System theory in management emphasizes the interrelated nature of different parts or components within an organization, and it views the organization as a unified and interconnected whole.

 

B. Contingency theory matches with "Based on open-systems theory and recognizes that there are many internal and external factors that influence organizational behavior." Contingency theory acknowledges that the effectiveness of organizational practices depends on various internal and external factors or contingencies. It considers the influence of different factors on organizational behavior and decision-making.

 

C. Organization design matches with "Concerned with formal patterns of arrangements and relationships developed by Management." Organization design involves structuring an organization to optimize its efficiency and effectiveness. It focuses on the formal arrangements, structures, and relationships within an organization.

 

D. Total Quality Management (TQM) matches with "Customer-oriented approach emphasizing human resources and quantitative methods to continuously improve." TQM is an approach that emphasizes continuous improvement, customer satisfaction, and the involvement of all employees. It uses quantitative methods and human resources to enhance the quality and performance of an organization.

Question 36
The present context of work organization is changing very fast. Lawler contrasted the ‘Old Logic’ with the ‘New Logic’ in this regard.Which of the following statements are the Lawler’s propositions on ‘New Logic’? (UGC NET HRM Aug 2016)(a) Bureaucracy is the most effective source of control.(b) Lateral processes are key to organisational effectiveness.(c) Top management and technical experts should add most of the value.(d) Organisations should be designed around products.(e) Effective leadership is the key to organizational effectiveness.(f) Organisation is a secondary source of advantage.
  • A.(a), (c) and (e)
  • B.(b), (d) and (e)
  • C.(b), (d) and (f)
  • D.(a), (c), (d) and (f)
Correct Answer: (b), (d) and (f)

Edward E. Lawler III is a prominent organizational theorist, and he has discussed the shift from the "Old Logic" to the "New Logic" in the context of work organizations. The Old Logic represents traditional and bureaucratic approaches to organizational management, while the New Logic reflects more contemporary and adaptive perspectives. Here are the key propositions for each:

 

Old Logic:

 

1. Bureaucracy is the most effective source of control: This proposition suggests that traditional bureaucratic structures, characterized by hierarchical control and formal rules and procedures, were considered the most effective way to manage and control organizations in the past.

 

2. Top management and technical experts should add most of the value: In the Old Logic, the emphasis is often on top-down decision-making and the contributions of technical experts. This reflects a more centralized and hierarchical approach to organizational functioning.

 

3. Organizations should be designed around functions: The Old Logic often organized companies based on functional departments (e.g., marketing, finance, operations). Each department operated somewhat independently, and communication tended to flow vertically through the hierarchy.

 

New Logic:

 

1. Lateral processes are key to organizational effectiveness: Lawler suggests that in the New Logic, lateral or horizontal processes, involving collaboration and communication across different parts of the organization, are crucial for effectiveness. This emphasizes a more networked and interconnected approach.

 

2. Organizations should be designed around products: Instead of a functional structure, the New Logic proposes organizing around products or services. This facilitates a more customer-focused and flexible structure that can adapt to changes in the external environment.

 

3. Organization is a secondary source of advantage: In the New Logic, the organization itself is seen as a secondary source of advantage. Instead, the focus is on the capabilities of individuals, teams, and the organization's ability to adapt and innovate.

Question 37
Given below are some of the terms along with authors associated with them, which of the following pairs are correctly matched? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2019)(a) Product Life Cycle - Vernon(b) Core Competence - Reich(c) Zero-sum Nationalism –Prahaladand Hamel(d) Balanced Score Card – NortonSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(b) and (c)
  • C.(b) and (d)
  • D.(a) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a) and (d)

Here's an explanation of the matched pairs:

 

Balanced Score Card – Norton

The Balanced Scorecard is a strategic management tool developed by Robert Kaplan and David Norton. It's designed to translate an organization's mission and strategy into a set of performance measures that provide a comprehensive view of the organization. The balanced scorecard approach incorporates both financial and non-financial measures to evaluate an organization's performance. It considers perspectives such as financial, customer, internal processes, and learning and growth, providing a more holistic view beyond just financial metrics.

 

Product Life Cycle - Vernon

Vernon's work focused on the international product life cycle theory, which outlined the phases that products go through in terms of their international competitiveness. He identified three main phases: the initial high-tech phase emphasizing research and development, followed by a growth and internationalization phase focusing on market development and penetration, and finally, the maturity phase aiming to lower costs through efficiency measures.

Question 38
Which of the following is ‘not’ true in case of ‘system’ theory of organization? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2009)
  • A.Organization is an energetic input-output system.
  • B.The system is flagrantly open in its interaction with the environment.
  • C.There is no negative entropy in a system which require importing of more energy from the environment than is expended.
  • D.For homeostasis in a system, the feedback loop is essential.
Correct Answer: There is no negative entropy in a system which require importing of more energy from the environment than is expended.

The correct answer is indeed (C) There is no negative entropy in a system which requires importing more energy from the environment than is expended. This statement is not true in the context of system theory. In systems theory, negative entropy refers to the idea that systems need to import more energy (or resources) than they expend in order to maintain their internal order and functioning. This principle is essential for understanding how open systems, including organizations, operate and remain viable. The importation of energy or resources from the environment is a key characteristic of open systems, and it is necessary to counter the natural tendency toward entropy or disorder.

Question 39
Match the items in List-I with items in List-II. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2011)List – Ia. Peter F.Drukerb. F.W. Taylorc. Henri J. Fayold. Hugo MunsterbergList – IIi. M.B.O.ii. Scientific Managementiii. Industrial Psychologyiv. Functional Theory
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii
  • C.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-i, b-ii, c-iv, d-iii

The correct matching of items in List-I with items in List-II is as follows:

 

a. Peter F. Drucker - M.B.O. (Management by Objectives)

b. F.W. Taylor - Scientific Management

c. Henri J. Fayol - Functional Theory

d. Hugo Munsterberg - Industrial Psychology

 

Here's an explanation for each of the matches:

 

a. Peter F. Drucker is well-known for his contributions to management by objectives (M.B.O.). M.B.O. is a management approach that emphasizes setting clear objectives and goals for employees and then monitoring their performance to achieve those objectives. Drucker's work has been instrumental in promoting the idea of aligning individual and organizational goals through objective setting and performance measurement.

 

b. F.W. Taylor is the pioneer of scientific management. Scientific management focuses on the systematic study of work processes to improve worker efficiency and productivity. Taylor's work laid the foundation for the principles of scientific management, which include time and motion studies, standardization of work methods, and the idea of matching workers to their tasks based on skill and capability.

 

c. Henri J. Fayol is associated with the functional theory of management. Fayol's work emphasized the five functions of management: planning, organizing, commanding, coordinating, and controlling. He also introduced the principles of management, such as unity of command, unity of direction, and the scalar chain, which have been influential in shaping modern management practices.

 

d. Hugo Munsterberg was a pioneer in the field of industrial psychology. He is known for his contributions to understanding human behavior in the workplace, particularly in areas related to personnel selection, training, and motivation. Industrial psychology focuses on how psychological principles can be applied to improve employee performance and well-being in an organizational context.

Question 40
Match the items of List - IwithList - II ; and choose the correct code of combination : (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)List - I(a) The Fundamentals of Top Management(b) Middle Management(c) The Essence of Management(d) Principles and Practice of ManagementList - II(i) Peter F. Drucker(ii) Ralph C. Davis(iii) E.L.F.Brech(iv) Mary Cushing Howard Niles
  • A.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(iii), d-(i)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(iii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)

The correct matching of items in List-I with items in List-II is as follows:

(a) The Fundamentals of Top Management - Ralph C. Davis

(b) Middle Management - Mary Cushing Howard Niles

(c) The Essence of Management - Peter F. Drucker

(d) Principles and Practice of Management - E.L.F. Brech

 

So, the correct code of combination is (B): a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)

Question 41
According to the Contingency Approach, the factors governing the Span of Management are: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)A. Type of workB. Ability of the managerC. Ability of the employeesD. Level of managementE. Geographic locationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.A, D and E only
  • D.A, B, C, D and E
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D and E

The Contingency Approach in management emphasizes that there is no one-size-fits-all solution in management practices. Instead, the effectiveness of managerial decisions and actions depends on the specific circumstances or contingencies in a given situation. When it comes to the span of management, which refers to the number of subordinates or employees that a manager can effectively supervise, several factors come into play:

 

A. Type of work: The nature of the work being performed by the subordinates is an essential factor. If the work is routine and repetitive, it may require less direct supervision, allowing for a wider span of management. In contrast, more complex or specialized tasks might necessitate a narrower span.

 

B. Ability of the manager: A manager's leadership, decision-making, and communication skills play a significant role in determining the appropriate span of control. If a manager is highly capable, they may be able to effectively supervise a larger number of subordinates.

 

C. Ability of the employees: The skill, efficiency, and knowledge of the employees also influence the span of control. If employees are highly competent and require less direct supervision, a wider span may be feasible.

 

D. Level of management: The level of management within the organizational hierarchy matters. Top-level managers may have a narrower span of control because they are primarily engaged in strategic planning and decision-making. Middle or lower-level managers may have wider spans of control as they deal with more day-to-day operations.

 

E. Geographic location: The physical distribution of employees in different geographic locations can impact the span of management. If a manager has to oversee a team that is spread across various locations, it may be challenging to manage effectively, and a smaller span of control may be preferred.

Question 42
Which of the following approaches to management is a reactive approach instead of being proactive? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2015)
  • A.Systems approach
  • B.Quantitative approach
  • C.Decision theory approach
  • D.Contingency approach
Correct Answer: Contingency approach

The Contingency Approach to management is generally considered a reactive approach rather than a proactive one. This approach suggests that there is no universal or one-size-fits-all management solution and that management practices should be adapted to specific situations or contingencies. In other words, management decisions and actions should react to the unique circumstances faced by an organization.

 

The contingency approach emphasizes that effective management depends on identifying and responding to the specific needs and challenges in a given situation. It's a response to the recognition that what works in one context may not work in another. Managers using the contingency approach react to the contingencies they encounter rather than proactively implementing a predefined set of management principles or practices.

 

In contrast, approaches like the systems approach, quantitative approach, and decision theory approach may involve more proactive planning, analysis, and decision-making processes. These approaches often aim to provide systematic and structured methods for managing and problem-solving.

Question 43
Match the following: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2011)Approach to Managementa. Management science approachb. Situational approachc. Interpersonal behaviour approachd. System approachCharacteristicsi. Focus on leadership and motivationii. Managerial practices depend on circumstancesiii. Use of mathematical symbol and relationshipiv. Recognizing the importance of inter-relatedness of management functions and sub-systems.
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv
  • C.a-iii, b-ii, c-i, d-iv
  • D.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-ii, c-i, d-iv

Here's an explanation of the matching of characteristics with the approaches to management:

 

a. Management Science Approach: This approach focuses on the application of mathematical symbols, models, and quantitative methods to analyze and solve management problems. It involves using mathematical tools, operations research, statistics, and computer simulations to make decisions and improve organizational processes. This approach is characterized by the extensive use of mathematical symbols and relationships to optimize various aspects of management.

 

b. Situational Approach: The situational approach, also known as the contingency approach, emphasizes that management practices should be adapted to the specific circumstances or situations at hand. It recognizes that there is no one-size-fits-all solution in management and that the best approach depends on the unique context of a given situation. Managers need to consider various factors such as the environment, organizational culture, and individual characteristics when making decisions.

 

c. Interpersonal Behavior Approach: This approach places a strong emphasis on understanding and managing human behavior in organizations. It focuses on leadership, motivation, and interpersonal relationships within the workplace. Managers adopting this approach aim to inspire and guide their employees, emphasizing the importance of effective communication, teamwork, and building positive working relationships.

 

d. System Approach: The systems approach to management views an organization as a complex and interconnected system with various subsystems. It recognizes the interrelatedness of different functions and processes within an organization. Managers using this approach consider the organization as a whole and analyze how changes in one area may affect other parts of the system. It encourages a holistic view of management, emphasizing the importance of understanding the relationships between various components of the organization.

 

So, the matching of characteristics with the approaches is as follows:

a. Management science approach - iii. Use of mathematical symbols and relationships

b. Situational approach - ii. Managerial practices depend on circumstances

c. Interpersonal behavior approach - i. Focus on leadership and motivation

d. System approach - iv. Recognizing the importance of interrelatedness of management functions and sub-systems

Question 44
Match the following. (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)List I(a) Application of psychology to industry and management(b) Program Evaluation and Review Technique(c) Widely acclaimed first lady of management(d) Application of psychology to advertising, marketing and personnel.List II(i) Henry L. Gantt(ii) Walter Dill Scott(iii) Lillian Gilbreth(iv) Hugo MunsterbergSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(iii)
  • B.(a)-(iv), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(ii)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(iv), (c)-(i), (d)-(ii)
  • D.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iv), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(ii)

Here's an explanation of the matching between List I and List II:

 

(a) Application of psychology to industry and management - (iv) Hugo Munsterberg:

Hugo Munsterberg was a pioneer in the field of industrial psychology, which involves applying psychological principles and methods to solve problems related to industry and management. He made significant contributions to the selection and training of personnel and the application of psychology to various aspects of business.

 

(b) Program Evaluation and Review Technique - (i) Henry L. Gantt:

Henry L. Gantt was known for developing the Gantt chart, which is a visual tool used for planning and scheduling projects. While not directly related to Program Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT), his work laid the foundation for project management techniques like PERT.

 

(c) Widely acclaimed first lady of management - (iii) Lillian Gilbreth:

Lillian Gilbreth was a pioneering figure in the field of management and industrial engineering. She is often referred to as the "first lady of management" and made significant contributions to time and motion studies, human factors engineering, and management principles.

 

(d) Application of psychology to advertising, marketing, and personnel - (ii) Walter Dill Scott:

Walter Dill Scott made significant contributions to the application of psychology in advertising, marketing, and personnel management. He emphasized the importance of understanding human psychology and behavior in these fields.

Question 45
Which of the following statements are true/false? (UGC NET HRM Jul 2018)a. Organisation Behaviour (OB) has been influenced by the; Contingency Approach, and The Interactional Approach.b. Hawthorne studies led to Human Relations Movement.c. Human Relations Movement’s main emphasis was an economic need i.e., people were more motivated by economic needs rather than Social needs.d. McGregor and Maslow were not the main proponents and figure heads of the Human Relations movement.
  • A.a, b, c are true, d is false.
  • B.cand d are true; a and b are false.
  • C.band d are true; a and c are false.
  • D.aand b are true; c and d are false.
Correct Answer: aand b are true; c and d are false.

Let us evaluate each statement:

 

a. Organization Behavior (OB) has been influenced by the Contingency Approach and The Interactional Approach.

This statement is true. Organizational Behavior has indeed been influenced by various approaches, including the Contingency Approach and The Interactional Approach.

 

b. Hawthorne studies led to Human Relations Movement.

This statement is true. The Hawthorne studies conducted at the Western Electric Hawthorne Works in Chicago had a significant impact on the development of the Human Relations Movement in management.

 

c. Human Relations Movement's main emphasis was an economic need, i.e., people were more motivated by economic needs rather than social needs.

This statement is false. The Human Relations Movement emphasized that people are motivated not just by economic needs but also by social and psychological needs. It highlighted the importance of factors such as social interactions, job satisfaction, and employee well-being in addition to economic aspects.

 

d. McGregor and Maslow were not the main proponents and figureheads of the Human Relations movement.

This statement is false. Douglas McGregor and Abraham Maslow were indeed key proponents and figureheads of the Human Relations Movement. McGregor is known for his Theory X and Theory Y, which emphasized contrasting management assumptions about employee motivation and behavior. Maslow's hierarchy of needs theory also contributed to the understanding of human motivation within organizations.

 

So, the correct answer is option (D), where statements a and b are true, and statements c and d are false.

Question 46
List-I below gives some names who have contributed for development of different management functions/activities and List-II gives the specific functions they are associated with. (UGC NET HRM Jun 2019)List-I(a) Robert Owen(b) Henry Fayol(c) F. W. Taylor(d) H. L. GanttList-II(i) Scientific Management(ii) Modern Personnel Management(iii) Work Study(iv) Modern Management Theory
  • A.(a)-(ii); (b)-(iii); (c)-(iv); (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(i); (b)-(ii); (c)-(iii); (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(ii); (b)-(iv); (c)-(i); (d)-(iii)
  • D.(a)-(iii); (b)-(i); (c)-(ii); (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii); (b)-(iv); (c)-(i); (d)-(iii)

(a) Robert Owen - Modern Personnel Management

A social and educational reformer, Robert Owen, is generally referred to as the father of personnel management. The Human Resources field evolved first in 18th century Europe from a simple idea by Robert Owen and Charles Babbage during the industrial revolution. These men knew that people were crucial to the success of an organization. They expressed that the wellbeing of employees led to perfect work. Without healthy workers, the organization would not survive.

 

(b) Henry Fayol - Modern Management Theory

According to the Administrative Management Theory / School, management is the process of getting things done through people. Here importance is given to groups and not to individuals. The first expert of Administrative Management Theory was Henri Fayol (1841-1925). Fayol is called the "Father of Modern Management". Henri Fayol was a French industrialist and a management consultant. He started the functional approach to management. Henri Fayol in his book titled "Industrial and General Administration" published in 1916, gave 14 principles of management.

 

(c) F. W. Taylor - Scientific Management

Human Resource emerged as a specific field in the early 20th century, influenced by Frederick Winslow Taylor (1856-1915). Taylor explored what he termed “scientific management” others later referred to “Taylorism”, striving to improve economic efficiency in manufacturing jobs. He eventually keyed in on one of the principal inputs into the manufacturing process—labor—sparking inquiry into workforce productivity.

 

(d) H. L. Gantt - Work Study

Work-study forms the basis for work system design. The purpose of work design is to identify the most effective means of achieving necessary functions. Historically, this work-study aims at improving the existing and purposed ways of doing work and establishing standard times for work performance. For this purpose, H. L. Gantt has developed a simplified graph which represents/displays the planned starting and finishing time of each task on a time scale. But it does not show the interrelationship among the tasks. On the left of the chart is a list of the activities and along the top is a suitable time scale. Each activity is represented by a bar; the position and length of the bar reflects the start date, duration and end date of the activity.

Question 47
Two lists are given below. Match both the lists and choose the correct answer from the code given below: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2018)List I(a) Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT)(b) Managerial Role Approach(c) Application of Psychology to Industry and Management(d) Principles of Scientific ManagementList II(i) F.W. Taylor(ii) Hugo Munsterberg(iii)Mintzberg(iv) Henry L. GanttSelect the correct answer using the codesgiven below:
  • A.(a)-(ii), (b)-(iii), (c)-(iv), (d)-(i)
  • B.(a)-(iv), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iii)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iv), (d)-(ii)
  • D.(a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iv), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(i)

The correct matching is given below:

Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) was given by Henry L. Gantt

Principles of Scientific Management were given by F.W. Taylor 

Hugo Munsterberg is considered to be father of Industrial Psychology

Managerial Role Approach was given by Mintzberg.

 

(a) Programme Evaluation and Review Technique (PERT) was developed by (iv) Henry L. Gantt. Although Gantt is more widely known for the Gantt chart, which he developed to schedule and track work in a project, he also made significant contributions to project management concepts like PERT.

 

(b) Managerial Role Approach is attributed to (iii) Mintzberg. Henry Mintzberg is well-known for his work on managerial roles and identified ten managerial roles that he categorized into three groups: interpersonal, informational, and decisional.

 

(c) Application of Psychology to Industry and Management is associated with (ii) Hugo Munsterberg. Hugo Munsterberg is often referred to as the "father of industrial psychology." His work contributed to the understanding of how psychology can be applied to various aspects of industry and management.

 

(d) Principles of Scientific Management were established by (i) F.W. Taylor. Frederick Winslow Taylor is widely recognized as the father of scientific management and is known for his principles aimed at improving industrial efficiency and productivity.

Question 48
Process orientation concept of management was developed by numerous authors. Who among the following is not associated with this concept? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2019)
  • A.McFarland
  • B.E. F. L. Breech
  • C.Lawrence A.Appley
  • D.George R. Terry
Correct Answer: Lawrence A.Appley

Lawrence A. Appley is not associated with the Process Orientation concept of Management. As Appley L. in his book has said “Management is the attainment of pre- established goals by the direction of human performance along pre-established lines. It is the management of people and not the direction of things.”

 

According to Appley L., management is essentially personnel management. We do not build automobiles, airplanes, refrigerators, radios etc. We build men and women, and these human resources build products. Human resources are our greatest assets. They have unlimited potential. Hence, it is but natural that management must give special attention to the development of human resources.

 

According to G. R. Terry, Management is a process consisting of planning, organizing, actuating and controlling, performed to determine and accomplish the objectives by the use people & resources.

 

According to Terry and Franklin - “Management is a distinct process consisting of activities planning, organizing, actuating and controlling, performed to determine and accomplish stated objectives with the use of human beings and other resources.”

 

According to Koontz and Weihrich - “Management is the process of designing and maintaining an environment in which individuals, working together in groups, efficiently accomplish selected aims.”

 

According to E.F.L. Breech – “Management may be defined as a social process entailing responsibility for the effective or efficient planning and regulation of the operations of an enterprise,” such responsibility involving (a) the installation and maintenance of proper procedures to ensure adherence to plans, and (b) guidance, integration and supervision of the personnel comprising the enterprise and carrying out its operation.”

 

According to Dalton E. McFarland - “Management is the process by which managers create, direct, maintain and operate purposive organizations through systematic, coordinated, co-operative human effort.”

Question 49
System Theory of organisation was given by: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2020)
  • A.Max Weber
  • B.Chester Barnard
  • C.Robert Owen
  • D.F. W Taylor
Correct Answer: Chester Barnard

Chester Barnard characterized all organizations as cooperative systems: “A cooperative system is a complex of physical, biological, personal, and social components which are in a specific systematic relationship by reason of the cooperation of two or more persons for at least one definite end.”

 

According to Barnard, willingness to serve, common purpose, and communication are the principal elements in an organization (or cooperative system). He felt that an organization did not exist if these three elements were not present and working interdependently. Barnard viewed communication as an energizing force that bridges the natural gap between the individual’s willingness to serve and the organization’s common purpose.

 

Barnard’s systems perspective has encouraged management and organization theorists to study organizations as complex and dynamic wholes instead of piece by piece. Significantly, he was also a strong advocate of business ethics in his speeches and writings. Barnard opened some important doors in the evolution of management thought.

Quiz Attempts 41-50 of 849
